For this, we focus on the term summarized as Cov(w^,p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (\hat{w},p\right)$\end{document}.Cov(w^,p)=1n∑i=1nw^ipi−1n2∑i=1nw^i∑i=1npi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathrm{Cov}\left (\hat {w},p\right)=\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\hat {w}_{i}p_{i}- \frac{1}{n^{2}}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\hat {w}_{i}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}$$\end{document}

Here we fill in ∑(k,l)∈Eβ^k,lpikqil\begin{document}$\sum_{\left (k,l\right)\in E}\hat{\beta }_{k,l}p_{i}^{k}q_{i}^{l}$\end{document} for w^i\begin{document}$\hat{w}_{i}$\end{document}1n∑i=1n(∑(k,l)∈Eβ^k,lpikqik)pi−1n∑i=1n(∑(k,l)∈Eβ^k,lpikqil)1n∑i=1npi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\sum _{\left (k,l\right)\in E}\hat {\beta }_{k,l}p_{i}^{k}q_{i}^{k}\right)p_{i}- \frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\sum _{\left (k,l\right)\in E}\hat {\beta }_{k,l}p_{i}^{k}q_{i}^{l}\right)\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}$$\end{document}

Because pi0qi0=1\begin{document}$p_{i}^{0}q_{i}^{0}=1$\end{document}, which makes 1n∑i=1npi0qi0pi=\begin{document}$\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{0}q_{i}^{0}p_{i}=$\end{document} 1n∑i=1npi=\begin{document}$\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}=$\end{document} pi0qi01n∑i=1npi\begin{document}$p_{i}^{0}q_{i}^{0}\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}$\end{document}, we can leave out the first term, which means this is also1n∑i=1n(∑(k,l)∈E∖(0,0)β^k,lpikqil)pi−1n∑i=1n(∑(k,l)∈E∖(0,0)β^k,lpikqil)1n∑i=1npi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\sum _{\left (k,l\right)\in E\setminus \left (0,0\right)}\hat {\beta }_{k,l}p_{i}^{k}q_{i}^{l}\right)p_{i}- \frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\sum _{\left (k,l\right)\in E \setminus\left (0,0\right)}\hat {\beta }_{k,l}p_{i}^{k}q_{i}^{l}\right)\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}$$\end{document}

and if we change the summation order, this becomes∑(k,l)∈E∖(0,0)β^k,l(1n∑i=1npik+1qil−1n∑i=1npikqil1n∑i=1npi)=∑(k,l)∈E∖(0,0)β^k,lCov(p,pkql)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum _{\left (k,l\right)\in E\setminus \left (0,0\right)}\hat {\beta }_{k,l}\left (\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{k+1}q_{i}^{l}- \frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{k}q_{i}^{l}\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}\right)=\sum _{\left (k,l\right)\in E \setminus\left (0,0\right)}\hat {\beta }_{k,l}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{k}q^{l}\right)$$\end{document}

Therefore, if there is any model wi=∑k,l∈Eβk,lpikqil\begin{document}$w_{i}=\sum _{\left (k,l\right)\in E}\beta _{k,l}p_{i}^{k}q_{i}^{l}$\end{document} that we believe generated the data, and for which we estimate the parameters using ordinary least squares (OLS), we can always write the following equation, which we call the Generalized Price equation in regression form, for this larger set of models.(GPE.R3)w¯Δp¯=∑(k,l)∈Eβ^k,lCov(p,pkql)+E(wΔp)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\sum _{\left (k,l\right)\in E}\hat {\beta }_{k,l}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{k}q^{l}\right)+E\left (w\Delta p\right)$$\end{document}

Because Cov(p,p0q0)=Cov(p,1)=0\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{0}q^{0}\right)=\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,1\right)=0$\end{document}, it, again, does not matter if we leave 0,0\begin{document}$\left (0,0\right)$\end{document} in or take it out.
This, first of all, encompasses the models that were included in Section 2.

Choosing E=0,0,1,0\begin{document}$E=\left \{\left (0,0\right),\left (1,0\right)\right \}$\end{document} here is the same as choosing R=1\begin{document}$R=1$\end{document} in Section 2; both give us the linear model, wi=α+β1,0pi+εi\begin{document}$w_{i}=\alpha +\beta _{1,0}p_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}$\end{document}, and since Cov(p,p)=Var(p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p\right)=\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$\end{document} the above equation becomes(1.4.1)w¯Δp¯=β^1,0Var(p)+E(wΔp)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1,0}\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)+E\left (w\Delta p\right)$$\end{document}

Choosing E=0,0,1,0,2,0\begin{document}$E=\left \{\left (0,0\right),\left (1,0\right),\left (2,0\right)\right \}$\end{document} here is the same as choosing R=2\begin{document}$R=2$\end{document} in Section 2; both give us the quadratic model, wi=β0,0+β1,0pi+β2,0pi2+εi\begin{document}$w_{i}=\beta _{0,0}+\beta _{1,0}p_{i}+\beta _{2,0}p_{i}^{2}+\varepsilon _{i}$\end{document}, and the above equation becomes(1.4.2)w¯Δp¯=β^1,0Var(p)+β^2,0Cov(p,p2)+E(wΔp)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1,0}\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)+\hat {\beta }_{2,0}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{2}\right)+E\left (w\Delta p\right)$$\end{document}
This setup also allows for models that are not included in Section 2.

Choosing E=0,0,1,0,0,1,1,1\begin{document}$E=\left \{\left (0,0\right),\left (1,0\right),\left (0,1\right),\left (1,1\right)\right \}$\end{document}, for instance, gives us a model with an interaction term between the p-score and the q-score, wi=β0,0+β1,0pi+β0,1qi+β1,1piqi+εi\begin{document}$w_{i}=\beta _{0,0}+\beta _{1,0}p_{i}+\beta _{0,1}q_{i}+\beta _{1,1}p_{i}q_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}$\end{document}, and the above equation becomes(1.4.3)w¯Δp¯=β^1,0Var(p)+β^0,1Cov(p,q)+β^1,1Cov(p,pq)+E(wΔp)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1,0}Var\left (p\right)+\hat {\beta }_{0,1}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)+\hat{\beta }_{1,1}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)+E\left (w\Delta p\right)$$\end{document}

This works for all models; the only thing that we need for this to work is that the statistical model includes a fixed term (for which we set the derivative to its coefficient to 0) and a linear term (for which we set the derivative to its coefficient to 0).

Also here, we can rewrite the regression form:(GPE.R4)w¯Δp¯=(∑(k,l)∈Eβ^k,lCov(p,pkql)Var(p))Var(p)+E(wΔp)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\left (\sum _{\left (k,l\right)\in E}\hat {\beta }_{k,l}\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{k}q^{l}\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)+E\left (w\Delta p\right)$$\end{document}

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: The Price equation in regression form can be generalized, also in a setting with two sets of genes, one captured by the p-score, the changes in which we track, and one by a q-score, the changes in which we do not track. The larger variety of possible true models, compared to models with a p-score only, is reflected in the larger variety of Price-like equations. Which one we can interpret meaningfully with how much confidence depends, as before, on completely standard statistical considerations concerning model specification and significance of parameter estimates.

sec.title: Minimizing the sum of squared errors and correlation coefficients
sec.p: Minimizing the sum of squared errors∑i=1nεi2=∑i=1n(wi−∑(k,l)∈Eβk,lpikqil)2\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}^{2}=\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (w_{i}- \sum _{\left (k,l\right)\in E}\beta _{k,l}p_{i}^{k}q_{i}^{l}\right)^{2}$$\end{document}

means that we set the derivative to βk,l\begin{document}$\beta _{k,l}$\end{document} to 0 for all k,l∈E\begin{document}$\left (k,l\right)\in E$\end{document}. This implies that we choose βk,l\begin{document}$\beta _{k,l}$\end{document} such that∑i=1n−2pikqil(wi−∑(r,s)∈Eβr,spirqis)=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^{n}- 2p_{i}^{k}q_{i}^{l}\left (w_{i}- \sum _{\left (r,s\right)\in E}\beta _{r,s}p_{i}^{r}q_{i}^{s}\right)=0$$\end{document}

and therefore we find that∑i=1npikqilwi=∑i=1npikqil∑(r,s)∈Eβr,spirqis=∑i=1npikqilw^i\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{k}q_{i}^{l}w_{i}=\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{k}q_{i}^{l}\sum _{\left (r,s\right)\in E}\beta _{r,s}p_{i}^{r}q_{i}^{s}=\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{k}q_{i}^{l} \hat{w}_{i}$$\end{document}

This also implies that the following quantity is 0 for all k,l∈E\begin{document}$\left (k,l\right)\in E$\end{document}.∑i=1nεipikqil−1n∑i=1nεi∑i=1npikqil=∑i=1n(wi−w^i)pikqil−1n∑i=1n(wi−w^i)∑i=1npikqil=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}p_{i}^{k}q_{i}^{l}- \frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{k}q_{i}^{l}=\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (w_{i}- \hat {w}_{i}\right)p_{i}^{k}q_{i}^{l}- \frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (w_{i}- \hat {w}_{i}\right)\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{k}q_{i}^{l}=0$$\end{document}

If we scale the last expression, to account for the number of observations, and for the variance in ε\begin{document}$\varepsilon $\end{document} and the variance in pkql\begin{document}$p^{k}q^{l}$\end{document}, then this becomes the sample correlation coefficient between ε\begin{document}$\varepsilon $\end{document} and pkql\begin{document}$p^{k}q^{l}$\end{document}. This scaling is not important here, because, by construction of the minimization, we have just seen that the unscaled expression is already 0 for all k,l∈E\begin{document}$\left (k,l\right)\in E$\end{document}. If we are choosing between including a term k,l\begin{document}$\left (k,l\right)$\end{document} and excluding it from the statistical model, then we can first minimize the sum of squared errors for the model without the term k,l\begin{document}$\left (k,l\right)$\end{document}, and then consider whether the sample correlation coefficient between ε\begin{document}$\varepsilon $\end{document} and pkql\begin{document}$p^{k}q^{l}$\end{document} is a number consistent with what one would expect if the true model is the model without pkpl\begin{document}$p^{k}p^{l}$\end{document}. If it is, then we do not include the term k,l\begin{document}$\left (k,l\right)$\end{document}. If it is not, then we do include the term k,l\begin{document}$\left (k,l\right)$\end{document}. Again, this is the domain of statistical testing. We will return to this at the end of Section 2 in Appendix 2.

sec.title: 5. Modeling
sec.p: Part of statistics is having to choose between statistical models, based on data. That means that the best we can do is to maximize the probability that we pick the right model. Modeling, on the other hand, relieves us of that uncertainty, as the model is just whatever we choose it to be. That makes it even more clear that there is something to be gained from matching the model that we happen to have chosen with the right Price-like equation.

While we have seen that the literature is somewhat sloppy on how to use the Price equation on data, it is also not always very specific or precise on how the Price equation is to be used on models. In this section, we will first circumvent all complications by assuming that we have a deterministic model, without noise. This is of course totally unrealistic, but it allows us to make a point about over- and underspecification of Price-like equations in a modeling context. This point is similar to the point about over- or underspecification in a statistical context. Moreover, this point also carries over to a setting where we assume an infinitely large population. This assumption allows us to treat the population dynamics as deterministic, even if there is uncertainty at the individual level about the number of offspring. In later subsections, we will drop those assumptions and show how even well-specified Price-like equations have limitations in describing properties of dynamics in stochastic models that do not assume that the population size is large enough for models with infinite population size to be a good approximation.

For simplicity, we begin assuming asexual reproduction. All points made below carry over to a setting with sexual reproduction but are easier made without. At the end of this section, we will revisit heterozygote advantage, for which we do switch to sexual reproduction.

sec.title: Model A
sec.p: The first model is wi=α+β1,0pi\begin{document}$w_{i}=\alpha +\beta _{1,0}p_{i}$\end{document}. The absence of a noise term severely limits what values α\begin{document}$\alpha $\end{document} and β1,0\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}$\end{document} can take. If pi\begin{document}$p_{i}$\end{document} is binary, then the fact that numbers of offspring are integers means that we can also only choose integers for α\begin{document}$\alpha $\end{document} and β1,0\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}$\end{document}. If pi\begin{document}$p_{i}$\end{document} is restricted to be 0, 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document} or 1, then α\begin{document}$\alpha $\end{document} can still only be an integer, while β1,0\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}$\end{document} needs to be an even number. Larger sets of possible p-scores further reduce what values for β1,0\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}$\end{document} we can choose. If we assume infinite populations, with uncertainty at the individual level, but deterministic population dynamics, these restrictions are lifted, but for now, we just assume that they are satisfied.

A deterministic model implies that for any given parent population, represented by a vector of p-scores p\begin{document}$p$\end{document}, there is only one possible transition to an offspring population. For that one transition, we can use the Generalized Price equation in regression form, where the sum of squared errors is minimized and equal to 0, at α^=α\begin{document}$\hat{\alpha }=\alpha $\end{document} and β^1,0=β1,0\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{1,0}=\beta _{1,0}$\end{document}. Here we simply use the matching statistical model, which in this case only needs to include α\begin{document}$\alpha $\end{document} and β1,0\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}$\end{document}. The matching Price-like equation for this model isw¯Δp¯=β^1,0Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1,0}\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

where β^1,0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}$\end{document} does not depend on which p\begin{document}$p$\end{document} we choose and equals β1,0\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}$\end{document} for any composition of the parent population. This equation can therefore serve as a useful summary of the dynamics induced by the model.

sec.title: Model B
sec.p: The second model is wi=α+β1,0pi+β0,1qi\begin{document}$w_{i}=\alpha +\beta _{1,0}p_{i}+\beta _{0,1}q_{i}$\end{document}. Again, the deterministic nature of the model puts restrictions on the values we can choose for α\begin{document}$\alpha $\end{document}, β1,0\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}$\end{document}, and β0,1\begin{document}$\beta _{0,1}$\end{document}, but those restrictions would be lifted if we assume infinite populations, with uncertainty at the individual level, but deterministic dynamics at the population level.

As before, we can use the Generalized Price equation in regression form, where the sum of squared errors is minimized and equal to 0, at α^=α\begin{document}$\hat{\alpha }=\alpha $\end{document}, β^1,0=β1,0\begin{document}$\hat \beta _{1,0}=\beta _{1,0}$\end{document}, and β^0,1=β0,1\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{0,1}=\beta _{0,1}$\end{document}. The matching Price-like equation for this model is(5.B)w¯Δp¯=β^1,0Var(p)+β^0,1Cov(p,q)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1,0}\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)+\hat {\beta }_{0,1}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)$$\end{document}

in which β^1,0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}$\end{document} and β^0,1\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{0,1}$\end{document} do not depend on the choice of p\begin{document}$p$\end{document} and q\begin{document}$q$\end{document}, and are equal to β1,0\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}$\end{document} and β1,0\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}$\end{document}, respectively, for any composition of the parent population.

sec.title: Model C
sec.p: The third model is wi=α+β1,0pi+β0,1qi+β1,1piqi\begin{document}$w_{i}=\alpha +\beta _{1,0}p_{i}+\beta _{0,1}q_{i}+\beta _{1,1}p_{i}q_{i}$\end{document}. Here we jump over the details and go straight to the matching Price-like equation for this model, which is(5.C)w¯Δp¯=β^1,0Var(p)+β^0,1Cov(p,q)+β^1,1Cov(p,pq)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1,0}\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)+\hat {\beta }_{0,1}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)+\hat{\beta }_{1,1}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)$$\end{document}
These three examples together illustrate that, also when modeling, there is a multitude of Price-like equations that capture properties of the population dynamics implied by the model.

sec.title: Mismatching models and Price-like equations
sec.p: It is important to note that also in this modeling setting, all of these Price-like equations remain identities, and they can be combined, not just with the model with respect to which they minimize the sum of squared errors, but also with all other, possibly richer models, as long as they have a constant term, and a linear term for pi\begin{document}$p_{i}$\end{document}. As a symptom of such a mismatch, the coefficients in the Price-like equation stop being constants; they will vary with the composition of the parent population (the p\begin{document}$p$\end{document} and, if present, the q\begin{document}$q$\end{document} vector) if they are applied to other models. Another symptom is that the coefficients in the Price-like equation stop matching the according coefficients in the model.

sec.title: Applying the Generalized Price equation for Model A to Model B
sec.p: If we apply the Generalized Price equation in regression form for Model A to Model B, then the sum of squared errors can no longer be reduced to be 0 and is minimized at β^1,0=β1,0+β0,1Cov(p,q)Var(p)\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}=\beta _{1,0}+\beta _{0,1}\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}$\end{document}. The fact that the sum of squared errors is positive is noteworthy. The model is deterministic and has no errors, and yet the sum of squared errors in the Price-like equation is larger than 0. By lack of actual errors, this can only be caused by misspecification of the model. The value for β^1,0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}$\end{document} at which the sum of squared errors is minimized if we apply the Generalized Price equation in regression form for Model A to Model B follows from the fact that both w¯Δp¯=β^1,0Var(p)\begin{document}$\bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1,0}\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$\end{document} and w¯Δp¯=β1,0Var(p)+β0,1Cov(p,q)\begin{document}$\bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\beta _{1,0}\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)+\beta _{0,1}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)$\end{document} are identities. The first follows from the derivation of the Generalized Price equation, combined with Model A, and the second was established above for transitions generated by Model B. We therefore end up with the following identity:w¯Δp¯=β^1,0Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1,0}\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

where β^1,0=β1,0+β0,1Cov(p,q)Var(p)\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}=\beta _{1,0}+\beta _{0,1}\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}$\end{document}. This implies that β^1,0\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{1,0}$\end{document} no longer is a constant, as it varies with p\begin{document}$p$\end{document} and q\begin{document}$q$\end{document} through the Cov(p,q)Var(p)\begin{document}$\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}$\end{document} – term. It also implies that β^1,0\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{1,0}$\end{document} is not the linear effect for this model, which would be β1,0\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}$\end{document}.

sec.title: Applying the Generalized Price equation for Model A to Model C
sec.p: If we apply the Generalized Price equation in regression form for Model A to Model C, then the sum of squared errors can also no longer be reduced to be 0 and is minimized at β1,0+β0,1Cov(p,q)Var(p)+β1,1Cov(p,pq)Var(p)\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}+\beta _{0,1}\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}+\beta _{1,1}\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}$\end{document}. We therefore end up with the following identity:w¯Δp¯=β^1,0Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1,0}\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

where β^1,0=β1,0+β0,1Cov(p,q)Var(p)+β1,1Cov(p,pq)Var(p)\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}=\beta _{1,0}+\beta _{0,1}\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}+\beta _{1,1}\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}$\end{document}. This implies that β^1,0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}$\end{document} is no longer a constant, as it varies with p\begin{document}$p$\end{document} and q\begin{document}$q$\end{document} through the Cov(p,q)Var(p)\begin{document}$\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}$\end{document} – term and the Cov(p,pq)Var(p)\begin{document}$\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}$\end{document} – term. It also implies that β^1,0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}$\end{document} is not the linear effect for this model, which would be β1,0\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}$\end{document}.

sec.title: Applying the Generalized Price equation for Model B to Model C
sec.p: This would lead to more complex relations between, on the one hand, β^1,0\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{1,0}$\end{document} and β^0,1\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{0,1}$\end{document}, and, on the other, the true β1,0\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}$\end{document}, β0,1\begin{document}$\beta _{0,1}$\end{document}, and β1,1\begin{document}$\beta _{1,1}$\end{document}, but the idea is the same: misspecification leads to a positive sum of squared errors, when it is being minimized, and coefficients that change with the state of the parent population.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: Also with modeling, misspecification is possible. This leads to Price-like equations in which the coefficients are not constant.

sec.title: Expected changes
sec.p: If we do away with the assumption of a deterministic model, one could still hope for the (Generalized) Price equation to be correct in expectation. In order to explore that possibility, we go back to Model A, but now with noise. That means that we go back to writing the model as wi=α+β1,0pi+ϵi\begin{document}$w_{i}=\alpha +\beta _{1,0}p_{i}+\epsilon _{i}$\end{document}. Explicitly or implicitly, the noise is typically assumed to have mean zero, which makes α+β1,0pi\begin{document}$\alpha +\beta _{1,0}p_{i}$\end{document} the expected number of offspring of someone with p-score of pi\begin{document}$p_{i}$\end{document}. Numbers of realized offspring are obviously integers, limiting what values wi\begin{document}$w_{i}$\end{document} can take, but the fact that we assume (continuous) probabilities with which an individual has these integer numbers of offspring implies that α and β1,0\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}$\end{document} can be any number. The model then captures how the p-score affects the distribution of the number of offspring, summarized by α+βpi\begin{document}$\alpha +\beta p_{i}$\end{document} being the expected value of that distribution.

We begin by fixing a parent generation characterized by a vector of p-scores; p=p1,…,pn\begin{document}$p=\left [p_{1},\ldots ,p_{n}\right ]$\end{document}. Any choice for p\begin{document}$p$\end{document} also implies an average p-score p¯\begin{document}$\bar{p}$\end{document} and a ‘variance’ in p-scores Var(p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$\end{document}. The new generation, then, is a combination of n\begin{document}$n$\end{document} independent random variables, one for every individual, as given by the model. For any realization of these random variables, one could write the Generalized Price equation that belongs to Model A. With asexual reproduction and no mutation – which implies that Ew∆p=0\begin{document}$E\left (w\Delta p\right)=0$\end{document} for every realization of these random variables – this would bew¯Δp¯=β^1,0Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1,0}\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

It is worth stressing once more that this equation holds for every realization of the random variables. The average fitness w¯\begin{document}$\bar{w}$\end{document} and the value of β^1,0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}$\end{document} do, of course, depend on the realization, while the expected values of w¯\begin{document}$\bar{w}$\end{document} and β^1,0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}$\end{document}, obviously, do not (notice that these are proper expected values, which are a property of a random variable, as opposed to the Ew∆p\begin{document}$E\left (w\Delta p\right)$\end{document}-term in the Price equation, which is really just an average). The expected value of w¯\begin{document}$\bar{w}$\end{document} is the expected average fitness 1n∑1=1nα+β1,0pi\begin{document}$\frac{1}{n}\sum _{1=1}^{n}\left (\alpha +\beta _{1,0}p_{i}\right)$\end{document}. The expected value of β^1,0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}$\end{document} is β1,0\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}$\end{document}, because we have assumed that the data are generated by Model A, and that is what it means for β^1,0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}$\end{document} to be an unbiased estimator of β1,0\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}$\end{document}. All of this could make one hope that maybe the (Generalized) Price equation in regression form could reflect a property of the expected change in average p-score implied by the model. This hope is unfounded, as the following simple example shows.

Assume a population of two parents, one without and one with a certain gene; p=0,1\begin{document}$p=\left [0,1\right ]$\end{document}. Without the gene, the probability of having 0 offspring and the probability of having 2 is both 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}. With the gene, the probability of having 1 offspring and the probability of having 3 is both 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}. That implies that the model fits wi=α+β1,0pi+ϵi\begin{document}$w_{i}=\alpha +\beta _{1,0}p_{i}+\epsilon _{i}$\end{document}, where α=1\begin{document}$\alpha =1$\end{document}, β1,0=1\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}=1$\end{document}, and ϵi\begin{document}$\epsilon _{i}$\end{document} is 1 or -1, both with probability 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}.

This super simple model implies that there are four possible transitions, each with probability 14\begin{document}$\frac{1}{4}$\end{document}. Var(p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$\end{document} is a property of the parent population, so Var(p)=14\begin{document}$\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)=\frac{1}{4}$\end{document} for all four transitions. Below we list the ingredients of the Price equation in regression form for the 4 transitions, all of which happen with probability 14\begin{document}$\frac{1}{4}$\end{document}.

If the parents have 0 and 1 offspring, respectively, then w¯=12\begin{document}$\bar{w}=\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}, Δp¯=12\begin{document}$\Delta \bar{p}=\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}, and β^1,0=1\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}=1$\end{document}.

If the parents have 0 and 3 offspring, respectively, then w¯=32\begin{document}$\bar{w}=\frac{3}{2}$\end{document}, Δp¯=12\begin{document}$\Delta \bar{p}=\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}, and β^1,0=3\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}=3$\end{document}.

If the parents have 2 and 1 offspring, respectively, then w¯=32\begin{document}$\bar{w}=\frac{3}{2}$\end{document}, Δp¯=−16\begin{document}$\Delta \bar{p}=-\frac{1}{6}$\end{document}, and β^1,0=−1\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}=- 1$\end{document}.

If the parents have 2 and 3 offspring, respectively, then w¯=52\begin{document}$\bar{w}=\frac{5}{2}$\end{document}, Δp¯=110\begin{document}$\Delta \bar{p}=\frac{1}{10}$\end{document}, and β^1,0=1\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}=1$\end{document}.

This helps verify that the expected value of β^1,0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}$\end{document} is indeed β1,0=1\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}=1$\end{document}, as E[β^1,0]=14(1+3−1+1)=1\begin{document}$E\left [\hat {\beta }_{1,0}\right ]=\frac{1}{4}\left (1+3- 1+1\right)=1$\end{document}. Also, that the expected value of w¯\begin{document}$\bar{w}$\end{document} is indeed 1n∑1=1nα+β1,0pi=121+2=32\begin{document}$\frac{1}{n}\sum _{1=1}^{n}\left (\alpha +\beta _{1,0}p_{i}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\left (1+2\right)=\frac{3}{2}$\end{document}, as Ew¯=1412+32+32+52=32\begin{document}$E\left [\bar{w}\right ]=\frac{1}{4}\left (\frac{1}{2}+\frac{3}{2}+\frac{3}{2}+\frac{5}{2}\right)=\frac{3}{2}$\end{document}. The expected value of Δp¯\begin{document}$\Delta \bar{p}$\end{document}, on the other hand, is EΔp¯=1412+12−16+110=730\begin{document}$E\left [\Delta \bar{p}\right ]=\frac{1}{4}\left (\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}- \frac{1}{6}+\frac{1}{10}\right)=\frac{7}{30}$\end{document}. That implies that, while the (Generalized) Price equation in regression form holds for every realization, we cannot replace all terms in it by their expected values, as32∙730≠1∙14\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{3}{2}\cdot \frac{7}{30}\neq 1\cdot \frac{1}{4}$$\end{document}

In other words, it is not generally true thatE[w¯]E[Δp¯]=E[β^1,0]Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle E\left [\bar{w}\right ]E\left [\Delta \bar{p}\right ]=E\left [\hat {\beta }_{1,0}\right ]\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}
with expectations taken over the random variables regarding the reproduction.

In models with a fixed population size, all transitions have the same average realized fitness, because for all transitions w¯=1\begin{document}$\bar{w}=1$\end{document}. Examples are the Moran process, the Wright-Fisher process, and all models included in Allen and Tarnita, 2014. If we consider one and the same parent population, Var(p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$\end{document} is a constant, and for every transition, the Price equation in regression form tells us thatw¯Δp¯=β^1,0Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1,0}\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

This implies that, since w¯=1\begin{document}$\bar{w}=1$\end{document} for every transition, in this special case, we do haveE[w¯]E[Δp¯]=E[Δp¯]=E[β^1,0]Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle E\left [\bar{w}\right ]E\left [\Delta \bar{p}\right ]=E\left [\Delta \bar{p}\right ]=E\left [\hat {\beta }_{1,0}\right ]\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

sec.title: Relation to Grafen, 2000
sec.p: As a side note, we can try to reconcile this with (Grafen, 2000), results in which one might, at first sight, think contradict this. In this paper with the title “Developments of the Price equation and natural selection under uncertainty”, the Price equation is extended to cover uncertainty. Below, we will apply the steps taken in Grafen, 2000 to our example in order to illustrate the differences.

There are two ways in which the Price equation is used differently in Grafen, 2000. The first is that it uses the covariance form, and not the regression form. The second is that it does not use realized fitnesses but defines a new variable vi=wiw¯\begin{document}$v_{i}=\frac{w_{i}}{\bar{w}}$\end{document} for every realization. It then uses this relative realized fitness instead of the (absolute) realized fitnesses. Both of these changes are needed for the Price equation to remain an identity after taking the expected value on both sides, and below we will show that neither one of the two is enough on its own. It is also important to observe that if we were to go from the Price equation in covariance form to the Price equation in regression form, the change in variable from wi\begin{document}$w_{i}$\end{document} to vi\begin{document}$v_{i}$\end{document} would obstruct a meaningful interpretation of the regression coefficients that is stable across realizations. It takes some imagination to envisage scenarios in which a gene increases the expected number of offspring of an individual by 1 if that individual happens to find itself in a population with an average number of offspring of 1, while it increases the expected number of offspring by 2 if that same individual happens to find itself in a population with an average fitness of 2. One could perhaps think of this as a reflection of the effect of the carrying capacity, where the death rate increases as the population size grows, but even then the total number of offspring is more relevant than the average number of offspring per parent. The claim in Grafen, 2000 is therefore true, but also not very useful for describing population genetic dynamics, which would require the Price equation in regression form.

caption.title: Four transitions and the values for the terms in the Price equation.
caption.p: This is an overview of all terms that are in the different versions of the Price equation.

sec.p: In the table above, we first listed w¯\begin{document}$\bar{w}$\end{document}, Δp¯\begin{document}$\Delta \bar{p}$\end{document}, and β^1,0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}$\end{document} for all 4 realizations, as calculated above. Then we calculated Cov(p,w)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,w\right)$\end{document}. The regression coefficient for v\begin{document}$v$\end{document} instead of w\begin{document}$w$\end{document}, which we denote by ϑ^1,0\begin{document}$\hat{\vartheta }_{1,0}$\end{document} here, is simply β^1,0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}$\end{document} divided by w¯\begin{document}$\bar{w}$\end{document}, as the variable vi\begin{document}$v_{i}$\end{document} is defined as wi\begin{document}$w_{i}$\end{document} divided by w¯\begin{document}$\bar{w}$\end{document}. Finally, Cov(p,v)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,v\right)$\end{document} is Cov(p,w)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,w\right)$\end{document} divided by w¯\begin{document}$\bar{w}$\end{document} for the same reason.

From this table, we can see, as before, that it is not generally true that E[w¯]E[Δp¯]=E[β^1,0]Var(p)\begin{document}$E\left [\bar{w}\right ]E\left [\Delta \bar{p}\right ]=E\left [\hat {\beta }_{1,0}\right ]\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$\end{document}, as 32∙730≠1∙14\begin{document}$\frac{3}{2}\cdot \frac{7}{30}\neq 1\cdot \frac{1}{4}$\end{document}

Also, we can see that it is not generally true that E[w¯]E[Δp¯]=E[Cov(p,w)]\begin{document}$E\left [\bar{w}\right ]E\left [\Delta \bar{p}\right ]=E\left [\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,w\right)\right ]$\end{document}, as32∙730≠14\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{3}{2}\cdot \frac{7}{30}\neq \frac{1}{4}$$\end{document}

Also, we can see that it is not generally true that E[Δp¯]=E[ϑ^1,0]Var(p)\begin{document}$E\left [\Delta \bar{p}\right ]=E\left [\hat{\vartheta }_{1,0}\right ]\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$\end{document}, as730≠71225∙14\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{7}{30}\neq \frac{71}{225}\cdot \frac{1}{4}$$\end{document}

The only thing that is true is that E[Δp¯]=E[Cov(p,v)]\begin{document}$E\left [\Delta \bar{p}\right ]=E\left [\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,v\right)\right ]$\end{document}. This suggests that both the switch from the regression to the covariance form and the switch from w\begin{document}$w$\end{document} to v\begin{document}$v$\end{document} are necessary.

sec.title: Infinite populations
sec.p: With ever-increasing populations, however, the variance in w¯\begin{document}$\bar{w}$\end{document}, p′\begin{document}$p^{\prime}$\end{document}, and β^1,0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}$\end{document} decreases ever more. In the limit of infinitely large populations, the dynamics become deterministic, and the (Generalized) Price equation in regression form will also hold again if we take expectations.

To illustrate this, we assume the same model as above, but now not with one parent without the gene and one with, but with infinitely many parents, while we still assume that there are equally many parents with and without the gene. Under that assumption, the dynamics become deterministic. That implies that w¯=32\begin{document}$\bar{w}=\frac{3}{2}$\end{document}, which coincides with the expected value for the example when there were only two members in the parent population. It also implies that β^1,0=1\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}=1$\end{document}, which also matches the expected value in the earlier setting, and Var(p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$\end{document} is also still 14\begin{document}$\frac{1}{4}$\end{document}. The only term that changes is Δp¯\begin{document}$\Delta \bar{p}$\end{document}; with deterministic dynamics, p′=1⋅0+2⋅11⋅1+2⋅1=23\begin{document}$p^{\prime}=\frac{1\cdot 0+2\cdot 1}{1\cdot 1+2\cdot 1}=\frac{2}{3}$\end{document}, which makes Δp¯=16\begin{document}$\Delta \bar{p}=\frac{1}{6}$\end{document}.32∙16=1∙14\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{3}{2}\cdot \frac{1}{6}=1\cdot \frac{1}{4}$$\end{document}

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: With infinitely large populations, it is useful to change the notation. Instead of going over individuals and representing what p-scores they have, one would have to go over p-scores and indicate the relative size of the population that has that p-score.

To keep it simple, we can think of a finite set of possible p-scores an individual can have, for instance 0,1L,2L,…,1\begin{document}$\left \{0,\frac{1}{L},\frac{2}{L},\ldots ,1\right \}$\end{document}. An infinite population can then be characterized by a vector x=x0,x1,…,xL\begin{document}$x=\left [x_{0},x_{1},\ldots ,x_{L}\right ]$\end{document}, in which xl\begin{document}$x_{l}$\end{document} measures the (relative) quantity of individuals with p-score lL\begin{document}$\frac{l}{L}$\end{document}. One can assume that these are shares of the total population, in which case ∑l=0Lxl=1\begin{document}$\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}=1$\end{document}. Alternatively, one can imagine that also with infinite populations, the size of the offspring generation as a whole may be larger or smaller than the parent population. This would require the possibility that population vectors do not add up to 1, which would make these numbers not only reflect the relative sizes of the set of individuals with different p-scores within one population, but also allow for a comparison of the size of the parent population and the offspring population.

To get comfortable with this notation, I will first write the (ungeneralized) Price equation in covariance form in this notation. The average p-score in the parent population would then be p¯=∑l=0Lxl∙lL∑l=0Lxl\begin{document}$\bar{p}=\frac{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}\cdot \frac{l}{L}}{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}}$\end{document}. The quantities in the offspring generation can be denoted by y=y0,y1,…,yL\begin{document}$y=\left [y_{0},y_{1},\ldots ,y_{L}\right ]$\end{document}, and these would be given by yl=xl∙wl\begin{document}$y_{l}=x_{l}\cdot w_{l}$\end{document}, where wl\begin{document}$w_{l}$\end{document} is the expected fitness of an individual with p-score of lL\begin{document}$\frac{l}{L}$\end{document}. With infinite populations, the randomness disappears, and we can treat wl\begin{document}$w_{l}$\end{document} as the average realized fitness for individuals with p-score of lL\begin{document}$\frac{l}{L}$\end{document}. The average p-score in the offspring generation is p¯′=∑l=0Lyl⋅lL∑l=0Lyl=∑l=0Lxlwl⋅lL∑l=0Lxlwl\begin{document}$\bar{p}^{\prime}=\frac{\sum _{l=0}^{L}y_{l}\cdot \frac{l}{L}}{\sum _{l=0}^{L}y_{l}}=\frac{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}w_{l}\cdot \frac{l}{L}}{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}w_{l}}$\end{document}, and the average fitness is w¯=∑l=0Lxlwl∑l=0Lxl\begin{document}$\bar{w}=\frac{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}w_{l}}{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}}$\end{document}.

We can use this to writew¯Δp¯=w¯(p¯′−p¯)=∑l=0Lxlwl∑l=0Lxl(∑l=0LxlwllL∑l=0Lxlwl−∑l=0LxllL∑l=0Lxl)=∑l=0LxlwllL∑l=0Lxl−∑l=0Lxlwl∑l=0Lxl∑l=0LxllL∑l=0Lxl=∑l=0Lxl∑k=0LxkwllL−∑l=0Lxl∑k=0Lxkwl∑l=0Lxl∑k=0LxklL\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\bar{w}\left (\bar{p}^{\prime}- \bar{p}\right) &=\frac{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}w_{l}}{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}}\left (\frac{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}w_{l}\frac{l}{L}}{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}w_{l}}- \frac{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}\frac{l}{L}}{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}}\right)\\&=\frac{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}w_{l}\frac{l}{L}}{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}}- \frac{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}w_{l}}{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}}\frac{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}\frac{l}{L}}{\sum _{l=0}^{L}x_{l}} \\ &=\sum _{l=0}^{L}\frac{x_{l}}{\sum _{k=0}^{L}x_{k}}w_{l}\frac{l}{L}- \sum _{l=0}^{L}\frac{x_{l}}{\sum _{k=0}^{L}x_{k}}w_{l}\sum _{l=0}^{L}\frac{x_{l}}{\sum _{k=0}^{L}x_{k}}\frac{l}{L}$$\end{document}

With xl∑k=0Lxk\begin{document}$\frac{x_{l}}{\sum _{k=0}^{L}x_{k}}$\end{document} being the relative share of individuals with a p-score of lL\begin{document}$\frac{l}{L}$\end{document}, in this new notation, the last expression is Cov(w,p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (w,p\right)$\end{document}. This gives us the standard, ungeneralized Price equation in covariance form.w¯Δp¯=Cov(w,p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\mathrm{Cov}\left (w,p\right)$$\end{document}

Here, we left out the Ew∆p\begin{document}$E\left (w\Delta p\right)$\end{document}–term, because with asexual reproduction, this is always 0. With sexual reproduction, this would also be 0 in the limit of infinitely large populations if we assume fair meiosis.

In this new notation, we can also derive the Generalized Price equation in covariance form, and also here the randomness disappears.w¯Δp¯=Cov(w^,p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\mathrm{Cov}\left (\hat {w},p\right)$$\end{document}

If we assume Model A, then in this notation, that means that wl=α+β1,0lL\begin{document}$w_{l}=\alpha +\beta _{1,0}\frac{l}{L}$\end{document}. If we fill this in in the formula for Cov(w,p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (w,p\right)$\end{document}, we getCov(w,p)=∑l=0Lxl∑k=0LxkwllL−∑l=0Lxl∑k=0Lxkwl∑l=0Lxl∑k=0LxklL=∑l=0Lxl∑k=0Lxk(α+β1,0lL)lL−∑l=0Lxl∑k=0Lxk(α+β1,0lL)∑l=0Lxl∑k=0LxklL=β1,0(∑l=0Lxl∑k=0Lxk(lL)2−∑l=0Lxl∑k=0LxklL∑l=0Lxl∑k=0LxklL)=β1,0Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathrm{Cov}\left (w,p\right) &=\sum _{l=0}^{L}\frac{x_{l}}{\sum _{k=0}^{L}x_{k}}w_{l}\frac{l}{L}- \sum _{l=0}^{L}\frac{x_{l}}{\sum _{k=0}^{L}x_{k}}w_{l}\sum _{l=0}^{L}\frac{x_{l}}{\sum _{k=0}^{L}x_{k}}\frac{l}{L}\\&=\sum _{l=0}^{L}\frac{x_{l}}{\sum _{k=0}^{L}x_{k}}\left (\alpha +\beta _{1,0}\frac{l}{L}\right)\frac{l}{L}- \sum _{l=0}^{L}\frac{x_{l}}{\sum _{k=0}^{L}x_{k}}\left (\alpha +\beta _{1,0}\frac{l}{L}\right)\sum _{l=0}^{L}\frac{x_{l}}{\sum _{k=0}^{L}x_{k}}\frac{l}{L}\\ &=\beta _{1,0}\left (\sum _{l=0}^{L}\frac{x_{l}}{\sum _{k=0}^{L}x_{k}}\left (\frac{l}{L}\right)^{2}- \sum _{l=0}^{L}\frac{x_{l}}{\sum _{k=0}^{L}x_{k}}\frac{l}{L}\sum _{l=0}^{L}\frac{x_{l}}{\sum _{k=0}^{L}x_{k}}\frac{l}{L}\right)=\beta _{1,0}\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

The (ungeneralized) Price equation in regression form, applied to Model A in an infinite population therefore isw¯Δp¯=β1,0⋅Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\beta _{1,0}\cdot \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

The Generalized Price equation, with Model A as a reference model, isw¯Δp¯=β^1,0⋅Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1,0}\cdot \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}
and if the model that this is applied to is Model A, then β^1,0=β1,0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1,0}=\beta _{1,0}$\end{document}.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: In stochastic models, the (Generalized) Price equation in regression form holds for every realization. That does not imply that it holds in expectation. However, if we assume that the population is large enough for the infinite population model to be a good approximation, then the Generalized Price equation in regression form will be informative about the dynamics. Misspecification concerns, of course, still apply.

sec.title: Heterozygote advantage revisited
sec.p: With the relation between modeling and the Price equation sorted out, we can revisit selection with and without heterozygote advantage. This means that we go back to a diploid setting, in which the p-scores can be 0, 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}, and 1.

sec.title: Model A
sec.p: First, we start with the linear model, which is wi=α+β1pi+εi\begin{document}$w_{i}=\alpha +\beta _{1}p_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}$\end{document}. We called this Model A at the beginning of this section, and we will also call it Model A here. We furthermore assume an infinite population and fair meiosis. Under those assumptions, the Generalized Price equation for the linear model, applied to the linear model, isw¯Δp¯=β^1Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1}\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

Here, β^1\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1}$\end{document} is equal to the true β1\begin{document}$\beta _{1}$\end{document}, and if we now would like to translate this equation into a criterion for whether or not (or, possibly: when) this gene is selected for, then this is really straightforward: at all frequencies, the gene is selected for ifβ1>0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \beta _{1}\gt 0$$\end{document}
In the Main Text, we will refer to this as the rule for selection of a non-social trait with linear fitness effects.

sec.title: Model B
sec.p: If we take the quadratic model, then the fitness function is wi=α+β1pi+β2pi2+εi\begin{document}$w_{i}=\alpha +\beta _{1}p_{i}+\beta _{2}p_{i}^{2}+\varepsilon _{i}$\end{document}. In the beginning of this section, we compared Model A to a different Model B, but here we will nonetheless refer to the quadratic model as Model B too, as it will be clear what this refers to here. The Generalized Price equation for the quadratic model, applied to the quadratic model, isw¯Δp¯=β^1Var(p)+β^2Cov(p,p2)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1}\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)+\hat {\beta }_{2}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{2}\right)$$\end{document}

Here, β^1\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1}$\end{document} is equal to the true β1\begin{document}$\beta _{1}$\end{document}, and β^2\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{2}$\end{document} is equal to the true β2\begin{document}$\beta _{2}$\end{document}. If we now would like to translate this equation into a criterion for when this gene is selected for, then this is still straightforward, but less concise: the gene is selected for ifβ1Var(p)+β2Cov(p,p2)>0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \beta _{1}\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)+\beta _{2}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{2}\right)\gt 0$$\end{document}

If we now furthermore assume random mating between generations, then at an allele frequency of p\begin{document}$p$\end{document}, the shares of individuals with a p-score of 0, 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}, and 1 are: 1−p2\begin{document}$\left (1- p\right)^{2}$\end{document}, 2p1−p\begin{document}$2p\left (1- p\right)$\end{document}, and p2\begin{document}$p^{2}$\end{document}, respectively. That makesVar(p)=E[p2]−E2[p]=142p(1−p)+p2−(122p(1−p)+p2)2=12p(1−p)+p2−p2=12p(1−p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right) &=E\left [p^{2}\right ]- E^{2}\left [p\right ]=\frac{1}{4}2p\left (1- p\right)+p^{2}- \left (\frac{1}{2}2p\left (1- p\right)+p^{2}\right)^{2}\\ &=\frac{1}{2}p\left (1- p\right)+p^{2}- p^{2}=\frac{1}{2}p\left (1- p\right)$$\end{document}

andCov(p,p2)=E[p3]−E[p]E[p2]=(182p(1−p)+p2)−p(12p(1−p)+p2)=14p+34p2−p(12p+12p2)=14p+14p2−12p3=12p(1−p)(12+p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{2}\right) &=E\left [p^{3}\right ]- E\left [p\right ]E\left [p^{2}\right ]=\left (\frac{1}{8}2p\left (1- p\right)+p^{2}\right)- p\left (\frac{1}{2}p\left (1- p\right)+p^{2}\right)\\ &=\frac{1}{4}p+\frac{3}{4}p^{2}- p\left (\frac{1}{2}p+\frac{1}{2}p^{2}\right)=\frac{1}{4}p+\frac{1}{4}p^{2}- \frac{1}{2}p^{3}=\frac{1}{2}p\left (1- p\right)\left (\frac{1}{2}+p\right)$$\end{document}
With random mating, the criterion for when this gene is selected for then becomesβ1+β2(12+p)>0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \beta _{1}+\beta _{2}\left (\frac{1}{2}+p\right)\gt 0$$\end{document}

Heterozygote advantage would mean that β1>0\begin{document}$\beta _{1}\gt 0$\end{document} and β2<0\begin{document}$\beta _{2}\lt 0$\end{document}, and if we for instance take β1=1\begin{document}$\beta _{1}=1$\end{document} and β2=−1\begin{document}$\beta _{2}=- 1$\end{document}, then that simplifies top<12\begin{document}$$\displaystyle p\lt \frac{1}{2}$$\end{document}

An important feature is that the rule for selection now depends on the population state, as Var(p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$\end{document} and Cov(p,p2)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{2}\right)$\end{document} are not multiples of each other. This implies that w¯Δp¯\begin{document}$\bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}$\end{document} may be positive for some and negative for other population states. With additional assumptions, such as random mating, this reduces to frequency dependence – which is something we should expect with heterozygote advantage. The β^1\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1}$\end{document} and β^2\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{2}$\end{document}, however, are not dependent on the population state, as they are equal to the true β1\begin{document}$\beta _{1}$\end{document} and β2\begin{document}$\beta _{2}$\end{document}, and therefore constant.

sec.title: The Generalized Price equation for Model A applied to Model B
sec.p: The Generalized Price equation for the linear model, applied to the quadratic model, isw¯Δp¯=β^1Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1}\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

with β^1=β1+β2Cov(p,p2)Var(p)\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1}=\beta _{1}+\beta _{2}\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{2}\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}$\end{document}. This also gets the direction of selection right for every population state, but here the β^1\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1}$\end{document} is not a parameter in the quadratic model. As a symptom of this, β^1\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1}$\end{document} depends on the population state. With the additional assumption of random mating, Cov(p,p2)Var(p)=(12+p)\begin{document}$\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{2}\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}=\left (\frac{1}{2}+p\right)$\end{document}, and therefore, under that assumption, β^1=β1+β2(12+p)\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1}=\beta _{1}+\beta _{2}\left (\frac{1}{2}+p\right)$\end{document}, which makes the β^1\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1}$\end{document} vary with p\begin{document}$p$\end{document}.

sec.title: Taking expectations with the Price equation in covariance form
sec.p: For a given state of the parent population, we can also take the expectation of the Cov(w,p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (w,p\right)$\end{document} term in the Price equation in covariance form. This is relatively straightforward. The expectation of a sum is the sum of the expectations; and since the expected value is a weighted sum, where the weights are the probabilities of all possible transitions, we can change the summation order in both terms. If we write E[wi∣p]\begin{document}$E\left [w_{i}\mid p\right ]$\end{document} for the expected value of wi\begin{document}$w_{i}$\end{document} given the state of the population, characterized by the vector p\begin{document}$p$\end{document}, we can writeE[Cov(w,p)]=E[1n∑i=1nwipi−1n2∑i=1nwi∑i=1npi]=1n∑i=1nE[wi∣p]pi−1n2∑i=1nE[wi∣p]∑i=1npi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle E\left [\mathrm{Cov}\left (w,p\right)\right ]&=E\left [\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}w_{i}p_{i}- \frac{1}{n^{2}}\sum _{i=1}^{n}w_{i}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}\right ]\\ &=\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}E\left [w_{i}\mid p\right ]p_{i}- \frac{1}{n^{2}}\sum _{i=1}^{n}E\left [w_{i}\mid p\right ]\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}$$\end{document}

It is still not generally true that E[w¯]E[Δp¯]=E[Cov(p,w)]\begin{document}$E\left [\bar{w}\right ]E\left [\Delta \bar{p}\right ]=E\left [\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,w\right)\right ]$\end{document}, as we have seen in the subsection above on the relation with (Grafen, 2000). However, if w¯=1\begin{document}$\bar{w}=1$\end{document} for every transition, as it is in models with a fixed population size, the following holds:E[w¯]E[Δp¯]=E[Δp¯]=1n∑i=1nE[wi∣p]pi−1n2∑i=1nE[wi∣p]∑i=1npi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle E\left [\bar{w}\right ]E\left [\Delta \bar{p}\right ]=E\left [\Delta \bar{p}\right ]=\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}E\left [w_{i}\mid p\right ]p_{i}- \frac{1}{n^{2}}\sum _{i=1}^{n}E\left [w_{i}\mid p\right ]\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}$$\end{document}

This is for instance very close to Equation 5.3 in Allen and Tarnita, 2014, who write wi(s)\begin{document}$w_{i}\left (\mathbf{s}\right)$\end{document} for what I denote as E[wi∣p]\begin{document}$E\left [w_{i}\mid p\right ]$\end{document}. Their wi\begin{document}$w_{i}$\end{document} therefore is the expected fitness, not the realized fitness. Their population state s\begin{document}$s$\end{document} moreover, is a vector, like our p\begin{document}$p$\end{document}, where si=1\begin{document}$s_{i}=1$\end{document} if individual i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} (or the individual at position i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} in a network) is type 1, and si=0\begin{document}$s_{i}=0$\end{document} if individual i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} is type 0. This implies that si\begin{document}$s_{i}$\end{document} can be interpreted as a p-score.

sec.title: 6. Discussion
sec.p: One of the contributions of the Generalized Price equation is that it helps explain the lack of convergence in the debate on the Price equation, as well as the lack of convergence in the debate on the results that are derived with it (which we will come back to in Appendix 2). If we draw the positions with somewhat broad strokes, then on the one hand, there is a majority position that has confidence in the method of using the original Price equation to derive results, and that believes those results to be correct and meaningful (see for instance Grafen, 1985a; Taylor, 1989; Taylor and Frank, 1996; Frank, 1998; Grafen, 2000; Rice, 2004; Okasha, 2006; Grafen, 2006; Gardner, 2008; Gardner et al., 2011; Rousset, 2015; Marshall, 2015; Queller, 2017; Luque, 2017). On the other hand, there is a minority position that disagrees with the results as well as the method (see for instance van Veelen, 2005; van Veelen et al., 2010; Allen et al., 2013; Allen and Nowak, 2015; van Veelen et al., 2017; van Veelen, 2018a; van Veelen, 2020a; van Veelen, 2020b). I claim that the lack of convergence in the debate is the result of looking at everything through the lens of the original Price equation, instead of the generalized version. The original Price equation in regression form, which we understand to be the Generalized Price equation in regression form applied to the standard linear model, is mismatched when paired with models that are different, or more general, or with data that do not support the standard linear model. Empirical or theoretical claims that would be correct and meaningful under the standard linear model, or for data that would support the standard linear model, are easily interpreted to also be correct and meaningful in general. This is facilitated by the fact that the original Price equation is an identity, which does not cease to hold when it is combined with models other than the standard linear model, or with data that are generated by other models. If not paired with statistics, the original Price equation does not differentiate between data that support the standard linear model and data that do not, when applied to data – and neither do the other Price-like equations we arrive at when we combine the Generalized Price equation in regression form with other statistical models. While most of the papers from the minority position, including mine, are negative, in the sense that they point to where this can be problematic, the Generalized Price equation not only points to the problem, but also gives a solution, as it helps formulate correct and meaningful alternatives to accurately describe the population genetic dynamics, when the way in which fitnesses depend on p-scores does not fit the standard linear model.

sec.title: It cannot be wrong because it is an identity
sec.p: The arguments in defense of the way the Price equation is used in the literature typically include the fact that it is an identity (and therefore that it cannot be wrong) as well as references to its generality. In order to counterbalance this, it is worthwhile, first of all, to point out that neither being an identity nor being general is all that special. There are literally infinitely many equations, all of which are identities, and all of which are completely general in the same way that the Price equation in regression form is general. In a failed attempt to be funny, I pointed out in an earlier paper (van Veelen, 2020b) that if we take the original Price equation in covariance form, and divide Cov(w,p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (w,p\right)$\end{document}, not by Var(p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$\end{document}, but by the Planck constant h\begin{document}$h$\end{document} times the number of times Denmark won the Eurovision Song Contest (denoted by DK\begin{document}$DK$\end{document}), then we can rewrite the Price equation asw¯Δp¯=Cov(w,p)h⋅DK⋅h⋅DK+E(wΔp)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (w,p\right)}{h\cdot DK}\cdot h\cdot DK+E\left (w\Delta p\right)$$\end{document}

As a next step, we can define γ\begin{document}$\gamma $\end{document} as Cov(w,p)h⋅DK\begin{document}$\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (w,p\right)}{h\cdot DK}$\end{document}, and writew¯Δp¯=γ⋅h⋅DK+E(wΔp)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\gamma \cdot h\cdot DK+E\left (w\Delta p\right)$$\end{document}

This equation is every bit as much an identity as the original Price equation in regression form, and it is also every bit as general. The equation as a whole, and the coefficient γ\begin{document}$\gamma $\end{document} in particular, however, is clearly devoid of any use or meaning. What this example illustrates is that it is not enough to be an identity. What we need is an identity with a meaningful interpretation. The original Price equation in regression form does have a meaningful interpretation for data that are generated by the standard linear model. We find that the Generalized Price equation, combined with different statistical models, produces other equations that also are identities and that also are general and that have a meaningful interpretation for data that are indeed generated by their presupposed statistical models. Having a meaningful interpretation, therefore, is limited to a subset of the models, or of the possible datasets, that the equations can be applied to. When dealing with data, one would have to resort to standard statistics to see if the data can inform us about the model that has generated them. Having a meaningful interpretation then is limited to those datasets that make us decide in favor of the model associated with any specific Price-like equation.

sec.title: What can we use the Generalized Price equation for?
sec.p: In a modeling context, we either directly assume a relation between p-scores and fitnesses, or we have a model that implies such a relation. For instance, we can assume a model wi=α+∑r=1Rβrpir\begin{document}$w_{i}=\alpha +\sum _{r=1}^{R}\beta _{r}p_{i}^{r}$\end{document} for some R\begin{document}$R$\end{document}, in combination with the assumption of unbiased transmission. Alternatively, we can make modeling assumptions that imply such a relation between p-scores and fitnesses. The corresponding Price-like equation in regression form then isw¯Δp¯=∑r=1RβrCov(p,pr)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\sum _{r=1}^{R}\beta _{r}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{r}\right)$$\end{document}

This implies that all terms on the right-hand side are a combination of a model parameter, βr\begin{document}$\beta _{r}$\end{document}, that is independent of the population state, and a term that reflects a property of a population state, Cov(p,pr)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{r}\right)$\end{document}. The equation then helps state how in infinitely large populations, the change in average p-score, corrected for the growth or shrinking of the overall population, on the left-hand side, depends on the combination of the current population state and the model parameters, which we see on the right-hand side. This now describes the population genetic dynamics for all population states, as the model parameters βr\begin{document}$\beta _{r}$\end{document} are constants that do not change with the population state. This may or may not be helpful for finding out properties of the model that we are interested in. In Section 4, we have also seen that we can choose richer sets of models too, as long as models in it include a constant and a term that is linear in the p-score.

caption.title: Nested models and their Price-like equations.
caption.p: There are different models, and each model has its own Price-like equation. These Price-like equations are general, in the sense that they can be written for any dataset, regardless of the underlying data generating process or, in a theory context, for any model. The terms in it, however, only have a meaningful interpretation if the data are generated by a model in the set that the Price-like equation belongs to. In line with the setup in this appendix, set A would represent models that are linear in the p-score (wi=α+β1,0pi\begin{document}$w_{i}=\alpha +\beta _{1,0}p_{i}$\end{document}). This is the set of models for which the regression coefficient in the original Price equation in regression form has a meaningful interpretation. Set B could consist of models that are quadratic in the p-score (wi=α+β1,0pi+β2,0pi2\begin{document}$w_{i}=\alpha +\beta _{1,0}p_{i}+\beta _{2,0}p_{i}^{2}$\end{document}), set C could consist of models that also include a coefficient for the p-score to the power 3 (wi=α+β1,0pi++β2,0pi2+β3,0pi3\begin{document}$w_{i}=\alpha +\beta _{1,0}p_{i}++\beta _{2,0}p_{i}^{2}+\beta _{3,0}p_{i}^{3}$\end{document}), set D models that are linear in the p-score and the q-score (wi=α+β1,0pi+β0,1qi\begin{document}$w_{i}=\alpha +\beta _{1,0}p_{i}+\beta _{0,1}q_{i}$\end{document}), and set E models that include an interaction term between the p-score and the q-score (wi=α+β1,0pi+β0,1qi+β1,1piqi\begin{document}$w_{i}=\alpha +\beta _{1,0}p_{i}+\beta _{0,1}q_{i}+\beta _{1,1}p_{i}q_{i}$\end{document}). The Price-like equations for these different models are all different.

sec.title: Dynamic (in)sufficiency revisited
sec.p: One possibility for a full model is that the way fitnesses depend on the genes that an individual carries is all there is to it. In that case, a model wi=α+∑r=1Rβrpir\begin{document}$w_{i}=\alpha +\sum _{r=1}^{R}\beta _{r}p_{i}^{r}$\end{document} maps any parent population state p\begin{document}$p$\end{document} to an offspring population state p′\begin{document}$p^{\prime}$\end{document}. For simplicity, we assume that this is a deterministic model, or an infinitely large population, which also makes this transition deterministic. (The numbering of the offspring generation, that is, which individual is labeled individual 1, and so on, is irrelevant; all covariances are invariant to permutations of the population vector). We can then iterate this update step, which makes this a dynamically sufficient population dynamics.

One reasonable observation to make here is that the Price equation itself is not something of which it is useful to describe it as dynamically sufficient or not; dynamic sufficiency is a relevant property of the model it is applied to, and not of the Price equation itself (van Veelen et al., 2012). If, on the other hand, one sees the Price equation as a tool to compute properties of the offspring generation, then it is tempting to describe it as dynamically insufficient. The Price equation gives the new average p-score and uses the old p-score and the covariances Cov(p,pr)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{r}\right)$\end{document} pertaining to the first generation to get there. If we then want to repeat this update step, and go from the second population state to the third one, we would need more than the average p-score in the second state, because now we also need the covariances Cov(p,pr)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{r}\right)$\end{document} pertaining to the second generation. These covariances in the second state we can get from the model itself, but we cannot get those from applying the Price equation to the first population state. In that sense, one could be tempted to say that the Price equation is not dynamically sufficient; once we have reduced what we know about a population state to its average p-score, we cannot apply it again. For more on the subtle difference between dynamic sufficiency and the necessity of higher moments, see sections 7–9 in van Veelen, 2018b.

In Appendix 2, we will use the Price equation in regression form to derive Hamilton’s rule, and there, we have a setting in which the q-score does not reflect the dose of a gene in the individual itself, but in its partner. The model can then describe how the fitness of an individual depends on its p- and q-score, and this would produce the p-scores in the new generation. It would, however, not generate which individuals are partnered up with whom in the new generation, and therefore it would not identify who has which q-score in the new generation. In this case, a full model would have to include more than the fitness function. In the absence of assumptions about the matching in the new generation, such a model would be dynamically insufficient.

Notice that this is not the same as the regression coefficients β^r\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{r}$\end{document}, or β^k,l\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{k,l}$\end{document}, depending on the population state, which is regularly also referred to as dynamical insufficiency. This is incorrect and really a symptom of misspecification. Describing the dependency of the regression coefficients on the population state as dynamical insufficiency is just not correct, and it can have the effect of not recognizing this as a red flag.

sec.title: Summarizing
sec.p: The paper in which the Price equation was presented was ambiguous about whether this was meant for statistics or modeling, and it was a bit loose with using terms from statistics and probability theory. That seemed harmless, but it has led to lasting damage in this field. Compared to the derivation of the original Price equation, it only takes a few extra lines of algebra to derive the Generalized Price equation. Behind those extra lines, however, hides an understanding that the original Price equation in regression form is really just one out of a variety of possible equations, and that the terms in it only have meaning if, when applied to data, the data for this transition justify the conclusion that they are generated by the linear model. When applied to a model, the terms in it are only meaningful if the reference model with respect to which the differences are squared, summed, and minimized coincides with the model under consideration. The original Price equation in regression form can, however, be written for any change between a parent and an offspring generation, also changes that are very unlikely to have been generated by the linear model that would give the terms in the classical Price equation in regression form meaning. For alternative models, one can write alternative Price-like equations, and those are equally general, in the sense that these can be written for any transition too. These other Price-like equations come with the same limitations on the interpretation of the terms in it; when applied to data, if the data do not justify concluding that the model the Price-like equation in regression form is built off of is accurate, the terms in it lose their meaning. When applied to a model, again, the terms in it are only meaningful if the reference model with respect to which the differences are squared, summed, and minimized coincides with the model under consideration. The Generalized Price equation does, however, offer a Price-like equation for every reference model. The classical Price equation in regression form is just one of them; the one for the linear model.

sec.title: The stationary distribution
sec.p: In order to be able to calculate the frequencies of the different p-scores in the offspring generation, we first establish that from the parent generation, all 4 parents with a p-score of 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document} survive, as well as 2 (out of the 4) parents with a p-score of 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document} (step 1 in Appendix 1—figure 2). Half of those are female and half of those are male, and therefore we can also think of this as a population where 12 out of 18 survive, 4 females and 4 males with a p-score of 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}, and 2 females and 2 males with a p-score of 1 (step 2).

These are randomly matched, which means that two thirds of the 4 females with a p-score of 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document} (out of 18 parents) are matched with a male that also has a p-score of 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}, and one third is matched with a male that has a p-score of 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}, resulting in 23418=427\begin{document}$\frac{2}{3}\frac{4}{18}=\frac{4}{27}$\end{document} parent pairs in which both parents have a p-score of 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}, and 13418=227\begin{document}$\frac{1}{3}\frac{4}{18}=\frac{2}{27}$\end{document} parent pairs with a female with a p-score of 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document} and a male with a p-score of 1. Similarly, there will be 13218=127\begin{document}$\frac{1}{3}\frac{2}{18}=\frac{1}{27}$\end{document} parent pairs in which both parents have a p-score of 1, and 23218=227\begin{document}$\frac{2}{3}\frac{2}{18}=\frac{2}{27}$\end{document} parent pairs with a female with a p-score of 1 and a male with a p-score of 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document} (step 3 and 4).

If both parents have a p-score of 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}, 1 out of 4 kids has a p-score of 0; 2 have a p-score of 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}; and 1 has a p-score of 1. If one parent has a p-score of 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document} and the other has a p-score of 1, then half of their offspring will have a p-score of 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}, and the other half will have a p-score of 1. Finally, if both parents have a p-score of 1, all of their offspring will have a p-score of 1 too (step 5).

All parent pairs have 3 kids on average, which then scales this back to the frequencies in the parent population. For example, that results in 3∙14∙427=19\begin{document}$3\cdot \frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{4}{27}=\frac{1}{9}$\end{document} kids with a p-score of 0, where 3 is the number of kids per parent pair, 14\begin{document}$\frac{1}{4}$\end{document} is the proportion of kids with a p-score of 0 that a parent pair gets when both parents have a p-score of 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}, and 427\begin{document}$\frac{4}{27}$\end{document} measures the number of such parent pairs (step 6).

sec.title: 1.5: Calculations for Example 3.3
sec.p: The average fitness is just the size of the offspring generation over the size of the parent population;w¯=mn\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}=\frac{m}{n}$$\end{document}

The change in p-score between the generations is one half times the difference between the frequency of females in the offspring generation and the frequency of females in the parent population;Δp¯=l+12(m−l)m−k+12(n−k)n=12(lm−kn)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Delta \bar{p}=\frac{l+\frac{1}{2}\left (m- l\right)}{m}- \frac{k+\frac{1}{2}\left (n- k\right)}{n}=\frac{1}{2}\left (\frac{l}{m}- \frac{k}{n}\right)$$\end{document}

If reproduction happens with equal probabilities on girls and boys, one would expect kn\begin{document}$\frac{k}{n}$\end{document} to be close to 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document} for large populations.

When calculating the Ew∆p\begin{document}$E\left (w\Delta p\right)$\end{document} term, we make use of the fact that all mothers have a p-score of 1, and therefore their successful gametes must all have p-score 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}. This implies that the sum of the p-scores of their successful gametes must be 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document} times the number of individuals in the offspring generation; ∑i=1k∑j=1mPij=12m\begin{document}$\sum _{i=1}^{k}\sum _{j=1}^{m}P_{ij}=\frac{1}{2}m$\end{document}. Also, it implies that wipi=wi\begin{document}$w_{i}p_{i}=w_{i}$\end{document} for all mothers, and therefore ∑i=1kwipi=∑i=1kwi=12m\begin{document}$\sum _{i=1}^{k}w_{i}p_{i}=\sum _{i=1}^{k}w_{i}=\frac{1}{2}m$\end{document}.

All fathers of daughters must have had a successful gamete with a p-score of 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}, while all fathers of sons must have had a successful gamete with p-score 0. Therefore, the sum of their successful gametes must be 12\begin{document}$\frac{1}{2}$\end{document} times the total number of daughters; ∑i=k+1n∑j=1mPij=12l\begin{document}$\sum _{i=k+1}^{n}\sum _{j=1}^{m}P_{ij}=\frac{1}{2}l$\end{document}. Also, it implies that wipi=12wi\begin{document}$w_{i}p_{i}=\frac{1}{2}w_{i}$\end{document} for all fathers, and therefore ∑i=k+1nwipi=∑i=k+1n12wi=14m\begin{document}$\sum _{i=k+1}^{n}w_{i}p_{i}=\sum _{i=k+1}^{n}\frac{1}{2}w_{i}=\frac{1}{4}m$\end{document}.

For mothers and fathers together, therefore, ∑i=1n∑j=1mPij=12m+l\begin{document}$\sum _{i=1}^{n}\sum _{j=1}^{m}P_{ij}=\frac{1}{2}\left (m+l\right)$\end{document}, and ∑i=1nwipi=12m+14m=34m\begin{document}$\sum _{i=1}^{n}w_{i}p_{i}=\frac{1}{2}m+\frac{1}{4}m=\frac{3}{4}m$\end{document}. ThereforeE(wΔp)=1n∑i=1n(∑j=1mPij−wipi)=1n(12l−14m)=12n(l−12m)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle E\left (w\Delta p\right)=\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\sum _{j=1}^{m}P_{ij}- w_{i}p_{i}\right)=\frac{1}{n}\left (\frac{1}{2}l- \frac{1}{4}m\right)=\frac{1}{2n}\left (l- \frac{1}{2}m\right)$$\end{document}

When calculating the Cov(w,p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (w,p\right)$\end{document} term, we use ∑i=1nwipi=34m\begin{document}$\sum _{i=1}^{n}w_{i}p_{i}=\frac{3}{4}m$\end{document} again.Cov(w,p)=1n(∑i=1nwipi)−1n2(∑i=1kwi+∑i=k+1nwi)(∑i=1kpi+∑i=k+1npi)=1n(34m)−1n2(12m+12m)(k+12(n−k))=3m4n−1n2(m)12(n+k)=3m4n−m2n−mk2n2=m4n−mk2n2=m2n(12−kn)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathrm{Cov}\left (w,p\right)&= \frac{1}{n}\left (\sum _{i=1}^{n}w_{i}p_{i}\right)- \frac{1}{n^{2}}\left (\sum _{i=1}^{k}w_{i}+\sum _{i=k+1}^{n}w_{i}\right)\left (\sum _{i=1}^{k}p_{i}+\sum \frac{k}{n}\right)$$\end{document}Var(p)=1n∑i=1npi2−1n2(∑i=1npi)2=1n(k⋅12+(n−k)(12)2)−1n2(k+(n−k)12)2=1n⋅14(3k+n)−1n2⋅14(k+n)2=34kn+14−(14k2n2+12kn+14)=k4n(1−kn)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle sec.title: 1.6: Calculations for Appendix 1—figure 1 from the Main Text
sec.p: In Model A from Appendix 1—figure 1, the number of offspring follows a binomial distribution with 10 trials and success probability 1101+pi\begin{document}$\frac{1}{10}\left (1+p_{i}\right)$\end{document}, where pi\begin{document}$p_{i}$\end{document} is the p-score of individual i\begin{document}$i$\end{document}. This results in an expected number of offspring of 1+pi\begin{document}$1+p_{i}$\end{document}, which means that the model can be summarized as wi=1+pi+εi\begin{document}$w_{i}=1+p_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}$\end{document}.

In Model B from Appendix 1—figure 1, the number of offspring follows a binomial distribution with 10 trials and success probability 1101+pi2\begin{document}$\frac{1}{10}\left (1+p_{i}^{2}\right)$\end{document}, where pi\begin{document}$p_{i}$\end{document} is the p-score of individual i\begin{document}$i$\end{document}. This results in an expected number of offspring of 1+pi2\begin{document}$1+p_{i}^{2}$\end{document}, which means that the model can be summarized as wi=1+pi2+εi\begin{document}$w_{i}=1+p_{i}^{2}+\varepsilon _{i}$\end{document}.

The variance of the error term is 1+pi9−pi10\begin{document}$\frac{\left (1+p_{i}\right)\left (9- p_{i}\right)}{10}$\end{document} for Model A, and 1+pi29−pi210\begin{document}$\frac{\left (1+p_{i}^{2}\right)\left (9- p_{i}^{2}\right)}{10}$\end{document} for Model B. These variances are not constant, and therefore the Gauss-Markov theorem does not apply. OLS estimators in the well-specified statistical model, therefore, are not guaranteed to have minimum variance. The error terms do, however, all have expected value 0, and that is a sufficient condition for OLS estimators in well-specified models to be unbiased.

For a parent population, in which all p-scores from 0 to 1, with increments of 0.1, have the same frequencies, as we have in Appendix 1—figure 1 in the main text, Var(p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$\end{document} and Cov(p,p2)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{2}\right)$\end{document} are calculated as follows.Var(p)=E[p2]−E2[p]=111∑i=010(i10)2−(111∑i=010i10)2=0.35−0.25=0.1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)=E\left [p^{2}\right ]- E^{2}\left [p\right ]=\frac{1}{11}\sum _{i=0}^{10}\left (\frac{i}{10}\right)^{2}- \left (\frac{1}{11}\sum _{i=0}^{10}\frac{i}{10}\right)^{2}=0.35- 0.25=0.1$$\end{document}Cov(p,p2)=E[p3]−E[p]E[p2]=111(∑i=010(i10)3)−(111∑i=010i10)(111∑i=010(i10)2)=0.275−0.5⋅0.35=0.1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p^{2}\right) &=E\left [p^{3}\right ]- E\left [p\right ]E\left [p^{2}\right ]=\frac{1}{11}\left (\sum _{i=0}^{10}\left (\frac{i}{10}\right)^{3}\right)- \left (\frac{1}{11}\sum _{i=0}^{10}\frac{i}{10}\right)\left (\frac{1}{11}\sum _{i=0}^{10}\left (\frac{i}{10}\right)^{2}\right)\\&= 0.275- 0.5\cdot 0.35=0.1$$\end{document}

The simulated numbers of offspring according to Model A result in an average number of offspring per parent of w¯=1.50411\begin{document}$\bar{w}=1.50411$\end{document} – which is close to 1.5, as it should be, given the fitness function, and the state of the parent population. Also, p′=0.565329\begin{document}$p^{\prime}=0.565329$\end{document}, which makes the change in average p-score equal to ∆p¯=0.065329\begin{document}$\Delta \bar{p}=0.065329$\end{document}, as the average p-score in the parent population is 0.5. This amounts to w¯∆p¯=0.0982618\begin{document}$\bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=0.0982618$\end{document}, which is the left-hand side, both of the Generalized Price equation in regression form assuming Model A and of Generalized Price equation in regression form assuming Model B.

If we apply the Generalized Price equation for Model A to these data to generate the righ-hand side, we find α^=1.01280\begin{document}$\hat{\alpha }=1.01280$\end{document} and β^1=0.982618\begin{document}$\hat{\beta}_{1}=0.982618$\end{document}, which results inw¯Δp¯=0.0982618=0.982618⋅0.1=β^1⋅Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=0.0982618=0.982618\cdot 0.1=\hat{\beta }_{1}\cdot \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

That means that the β^1\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1}$\end{document} is close to the true value of β1\begin{document}$\beta _{1}$\end{document}, which is 1. Notice that also α^\begin{document}$\hat{\alpha }$\end{document} is close to its true value, which is also 1, but this does not feature in the Price equation. Here we use Var(p)=0.1\begin{document}$\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)=0.1$\end{document}, as calculated above.

If we apply the Generalized Price equation for Model B to the same data, we find α^=1.01039\begin{document}$\hat{\alpha }=1.01039$\end{document}; β^1=0.998655\begin{document}$\hat{\beta}_{1}=0.998655$\end{document}; and β^2=0.016037\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{2}=0.016037$\end{document}.
