Therefore, this is also1n∑i=1n(∑j∈J∖(0,…,0)β^jqi1j1⋅⋅⋅qikjkpijk+1)pi−1n∑i=1n(∑j∈J∖(0,…,0)β^jqi1j1⋅⋅⋅qikjkpijk+1)1n∑i=1npi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\sum _{j\in J\setminus\left (0,\ldots ,0\right)}\hat{\beta }_{j}q_{i1}^{j_{1}}\cdot \cdot \cdot q_{ik}^{j_{k}}p_{i}^{j_{k+1}}\right)p_{i}- \frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\sum _{j\in J\setminus\left (0,\ldots ,0\right)}\hat{\beta }_{j}q_{i1}^{j_{1}}\cdot \cdot \cdot q_{ik}^{j_{k}}p_{i}^{j_{k+1}}\right)\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}$$\end{document}

If we change the summation order, this becomes∑j∈J∖(0,…,0)β^j(1n∑i=1nqi1j1⋅⋅⋅qikjkpijk+1+1−1n∑i=1nqi1j1⋅⋅⋅qikjkpijk+11n∑i=1npi)=∑j∈J∖(0,…,0)β^k,lCov(p,q1j1⋅⋅⋅qkjkpjk+1)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum _{j\in J\setminus\left (0,\ldots ,0\right)}\hat{\beta }_{j} & \left (\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}q_{i1}^{j_{1}}\cdot \cdot \cdot q_{ik}^{j_{k}}p_{i}^{j_{k+1}+1}- \frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}q_{i1}^{j_{1}}\cdot \cdot \cdot q_{ik}^{j_{k}}p_{i}^{j_{k+1}}\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}\right)\\& =\sum _{j\in J\setminus \left (0,\ldots ,0\right)}\hat{\beta }_{k,l}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q_{1}^{j_{1}}\cdot \cdot \cdot q_{k}^{j_{k}}p^{j_{k+1}}\right)$$\end{document}

For any choice of a model that this framework allows for – that is, for any choice of a set J\begin{document}$J$\end{document} – the Generalized Price equation in regression form therefore is(GPE.R5)w¯Δp¯=∑j∈J∖(0,…,0)β^jCov(p,q1j1⋅⋅⋅qkjkpjk+1)+E(wΔp)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\sum _{j\in J\setminus\left (0,\ldots ,0\right)}\hat {\beta }_{j}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q_{1}^{j_{1}}\cdot \cdot \cdot q_{k}^{j_{k}}p^{j_{k+1}}\right)+E\left (w\Delta p\right)$$\end{document}

Because Cov(p,q10⋅⋅⋅qn0p0)=Cov(p,1)=0\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q_{1}^{0}\cdot \cdot \cdot q_{n}^{0}p^{0}\right)=\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,1\right)=0$\end{document}, it does not matter if we leave 0,…,0\begin{document}$\left (0,\ldots ,0\right)$\end{document} in or not.

sec.title: Example B5.1: a linear model with more than one type of relative
sec.p: If we choose J=0,…,0,1,0,…,0,…,0,0,…,0,1\begin{document}$J=\left \{\left (0,\ldots ,0\right),\left (1,0,\ldots ,0\right),\ldots ,\left (0,0,\ldots ,0,1\right)\right \}$\end{document}, then this set consists of a constant; linear terms for all of the p-scores of the individuals it interacts with; and a linear term for the p-scores of the individual itself. With this as a reference model, the Price equation in regression form becomes.w¯Δp¯=β^(1,0,…,0)Cov(p,q1)+…+β^(0,…,0,1,0)Cov(p,qk)+β^(0,…,0,1)Cov(p,p)+E(wΔp)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat{\beta }_{\left (1,0,\ldots ,0\right)}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q_{1}\right)+\ldots +\hat{\beta }_{\left (0,\ldots ,0,1,0\right)}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q_{k}\right)+\hat{\beta }_{\left (0,\ldots ,0,1\right)}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p\right)+E\left (w\Delta p\right)$$\end{document}

If we rename the coefficients for brevity, so that β^(1,0,…,0)\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{\left (1,0,\ldots ,0\right)}$\end{document} becomes β^1\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{1}$\end{document}; β^(0,…,0,1,0)\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{\left (0,\ldots ,0,1,0\right)}$\end{document} becomes β^k\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{k}$\end{document}; and β^(0,…,0,1)\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{\left (0,\ldots ,0,1\right)}$\end{document} becomes β^k+1\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{k+1}$\end{document}, then we can write this asw¯Δp¯=∑l=1kβ^lCov(p,ql)+β^k+1Cov(p,p)+E(wΔp)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\sum _{l=1}^{k}\hat {\beta }_{l}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q_{l}\right)+\hat{\beta }_{k+1}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p\right)+E\left (w\Delta p\right)$$\end{document}

or, because Cov(p,p)=Var(p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,p\right)=\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$\end{document}, asw¯Δp¯=(∑l=1kβ^lCov(p,ql)Var(p)+β^k+1)Var(p)+E(wΔp)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\left (\sum _{l=1}^{k}\hat {\beta }_{l}\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q_{l}\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}+\hat {\beta }_{k+1}\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)+E\left (w\Delta p\right)$$\end{document}

If we are studying a model in which there is a number of types of relatives (such as siblings, cousins, etc.) and in which the p-scores of those relatives affect the fitness of the individual linearly – or, in other words, if the model that we are studying does indeed match the set J\begin{document}$J$\end{document} of this example – and if the population is infinitely large, then the coefficients in the Generalized Price equation, using the same model as a reference model, will coincide with the model coefficients – that is, β^l=βl\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{l}=\beta _{l}$\end{document} for l=1,…,k+1\begin{document}$l=1,\ldots ,k+1$\end{document}. Moreover, in an infinitely large population Cov(p,ql)Var(p)\begin{document}$\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q_{l}\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}$\end{document} will coincide with the relatednesses with these different types of relatives, for l=1,…,k\begin{document}$l=1,\ldots ,k$\end{document}, and, if we also assume fair meiosis, then Ew∆p=0\begin{document}$E\left (w\Delta p\right)=0$\end{document}. Therefore, if we denote the relatedness with relatives of type l\begin{document}$l$\end{document} as rl\begin{document}$r_{l}$\end{document}, and write bl=βl\begin{document}$b_{l}=\beta _{l}$\end{document} for l=1,…,k\begin{document}$l=1,\ldots ,k$\end{document} and c=−βk+1\begin{document}$c=- \beta _{k+1}$\end{document}, this gives us a rule for selection for the linear model that coincides with what we would have expected; Δp¯>0\begin{document}$\Delta \bar{p}\gt 0$\end{document} if and only if∑l=1krlbl−c>0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum _{l=1}^{k}r_{l}b_{l}- c \gt 0$$\end{document}

Here bl=βl\begin{document}$b_{l}=\beta _{l}$\end{document} is the linear effect on relatives of type l=1,…,k\begin{document}$l=1,\ldots ,k$\end{document} (these are the benefits of cooperation, assuming that they are positive), and c=−βk+1\begin{document}$c=- \beta _{k+1}$\end{document} is minus the linear effect on the individual itself (which makes it the cost of cooperation). This gives us a vector of fitness costs and benefits that is similar to the vector of fitness effects postulated in Hamilton, 1964a.

sec.title: Example B5.2: models with multiple interaction partners of the same type of relative
sec.p: If interaction partners 1 to k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} are all the same type of relative (for instance, if they are all full siblings) who are involved in the same type of interaction, then it would be strange to treat them separately, as the setup would impose a certain symmetry between them. For instance, it would be strange, when minimizing the sum of squared errors, to allow for the linear effect of the p-score of sibling 1 to be different from the linear effect of the p-score of sibling k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} or of any other sibling. In other words, if there is no reason to treat those different siblings differently, we would have to restrict the coefficients in J\begin{document}$J$\end{document} so that β^(1,0,…,0)=…=β^(0,…,0,1,0)\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{\left (1,0,\ldots ,0\right)}=\ldots =\hat{\beta }_{\left (0,\ldots ,0,1,0\right)}$\end{document}. More generally, the symmetry would dictate that all vectors in which the first k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} elements are permutations of each other should be restricted to be the same when the sum of squared errors is minimized. Just to give a few more examples of the restrictions that symmetry imposes, for k=3\begin{document}$k=3$\end{document}, besides β^(1,0,0,0)=β^(0,1,0,0)=β^(0,0,1,0)\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{\left (1,0,0,0\right)}=\hat {\beta }_{\left (0,1,0,0\right)}=\hat{\beta }_{\left (0,0,1,0\right)}$\end{document}, symmetry would also suggest that β^(1,0,0,1)=β^(0,1,0,1)=β^(0,0,1,1)\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{\left (1,0,0,1\right)}=\hat {\beta }_{\left (0,1,0,1\right)}=\hat {\beta }_{\left (0,0,1,1\right)}$\end{document}; and β^(1,1,0,0)=β^(1,0,1,0)=β^(0,1,1,0)\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{\left (1,1,0,0\right)}=\hat {\beta }_{\left (1,0,1,0\right)}=\hat{\beta }_{\left (0,1,1,0\right)}$\end{document}; and β^(2,0,0,0)=β^(0,2,0,0)=β^(0,0,2,0)\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{\left (2,0,0,0\right)}=\hat {\beta }_{\left (0,2,0,0\right)}=\hat {\beta }_{\left (0,0,2,0\right)}$\end{document}; and so on.

sec.title: Linear effects (and siblings)
sec.p: If we consider a situation in which all individuals interact with k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} partners, all of whom are related in the same way to the individual (for instance, they could all be full siblings), then one possibility would be the following linear model.wi=β(0,…,0)+β(1,0,…,0)qi1+β(0,1,0,…,0)qi2+…+β(0,…,0,1,0)qik+β(0,…,0,1)pi+εi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle w_{i}=\beta _{\left (0,\ldots ,0\right)}+\beta _{\left (1,0,\ldots ,0\right)}q_{i1}+\beta _{\left (0,1,0,\ldots ,0\right)}q_{i2}+\ldots +\beta _{\left (0,\ldots ,0,1,0\right)}q_{ik}+\beta _{\left (0,\ldots ,0,1\right)}p_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}$$\end{document}

This amounts to a choice for J=0,…,0,1,0,…,0,…,0,…,0,1\begin{document}$J=\left \{\left (0,\ldots ,0\right),\left (1,0,\ldots ,0\right),\ldots ,\left (0,\ldots ,0,1\right)\right \}$\end{document}. For this linear model, the symmetry implies that we impose that β1,0,…,0=β0,1,0,…,0=…=β0,…,0,1,0\begin{document}$\beta _{\left (1,0,\ldots ,0\right)}=\beta _{\left (0,1,0,\ldots ,0\right)}=\ldots =\beta _{\left (0,\ldots ,0,1,0\right)}$\end{document}. If we do impose this, the fitness function can be rewritten aswi=β(0,0,0)+β(1,0,…,0)∑l=1kqil+β(0,…,0,1)pi+εi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle w_{i}=\beta _{\left (0,0,0\right)}+\beta _{\left (1,0,\ldots ,0\right)}\sum _{l=1}^{k}q_{il}+\beta _{\left (0,\ldots ,0,1\right)}p_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}$$\end{document}

The Generalized Price equation in regression form for this model then becomesw¯Δp¯=(β^(1,0,…,0)Cov(p,∑l=1kqil)Var(p)+β^(0,…,0,1))Var(p)+E(wΔp)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\left (\hat{\beta }_{\left (1,0,\ldots ,0\right)}\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,\sum _{l=1}^{k}q_{il}\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}+\hat{\beta }_{\left (0,\ldots ,0,1\right)}\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)+E\left (w\Delta p\right)$$\end{document}

In a modeling exercise, besides a fitness function, we would also need a model for the population structure. This would be an explicit or implicit statement about who interacts with whom. In an infinitely large population, that would have implications for how Cov(p,∑l=1kqil)Var(p)\begin{document}$\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,\sum _{l=1}^{k}q_{il}\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}$\end{document} depends on the average p-score in the population. If we think of full siblings, such a model of the population structure for instance would have to imply that Cov(p,∑l=1kqil)Var(p)=kCov(p,qi1)Var(p)=k2\begin{document}$\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,\sum _{l=1}^{k}q_{il}\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}=k\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q_{i1}\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}=\frac{k}{2}$\end{document}. The rule for selection in the case of siblings then becomes that Δp¯>0\begin{document}$\Delta \bar{p}\gt 0$\end{document} if and only if k2β(1,0,…,0)>−β(0,…,0,1)\begin{document}$\frac{k}{2}\beta _{\left (1,0,\ldots ,0\right)}\gt - \beta _{\left (0,\ldots ,0,1\right)}$\end{document}.

sec.title: Weakest link game (and random matching)
sec.p: Here we consider a situation in which all individuals interact in groups of 3, and for simplicity, we assume that the p-scores are binary. We can then imagine a situation in which it requires all three group members to cooperate (have a p-core of 1) for a benefit for all of them to be created. In other words, we could imagine that the fitness function iswi=β(0,0,0)+β(1,1,1)q1iq2ipi+β(0,0,1)pi+εi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle w_{i}=\beta _{\left (0,0,0\right)}+\beta _{\left (1,1,1\right)}q_{1i}q_{2i}p_{i}+\beta _{\left (0,0,1\right)}p_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}$$\end{document}

with β^(1,1,1)>0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{\left (1,1,1\right)}\gt 0$\end{document} and β^(0,0,1)<0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{\left (0,0,1\right)}\lt 0$\end{document}. Cooperation is potentially good for fitness if β^(1,1,1)>−β^(0,0,1)\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{\left (1,1,1\right)}\gt - \hat{\beta }_{\left (0,0,1\right)}$\end{document}. This model would come down to a choice for a set of nonzero coefficientsJ={(0,0,0),(0,0,1),(1,1,1)}\begin{document}$$\displaystyle J=\left \{\left (0,0,0\right),\left (0,0,1\right),\left (1,1,1\right)\right \}$$\end{document}

The Generalized Price equation in regression form for this model then becomesw¯Δp¯=(β^(1,1,1)Cov(p,pq1q2)Var(p)+β^(0,0,1))Var(p)+E(wΔp)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\left (\hat {\beta }_{\left (1,1,1\right)}\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq_{1}q_{2}\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}+\hat {\beta }_{\left (0,0,1\right)}\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)+E\left (w\Delta p\right)$$\end{document}

If we assume an infinitely large population in which this model does indeed correctly describe the fitness function, then Cov(p,pq1q2)Var(p)\begin{document}$\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq_{1}q_{2}\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}$\end{document} will typically be frequency dependent. For instance, if we assume random group formation, then that implies that the share of groups of 3 that consist of m\begin{document}$m$\end{document} cooperators and 3−m\begin{document}$3- m$\end{document} defectors will depend on the average share p¯\begin{document}$\bar{p}$\end{document} of cooperators in the population as follows:fm(p¯)={(1−p¯)3ifm=03(1−p¯)2p¯ifm=13(1−p¯)p¯2ifm=2p¯3ifm=3\begin{document}$$\displaystyle f_{m}\left (\bar{p}\right)=\begin{cases} \begin{array}{c}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)^{3}if \,m=0\\3\left (1- \bar{p}\right)^{2}\bar{p}\,if\,m=1\\3\left (1- \bar{p}\right)\bar{p}^{2}\,if\,m=2\end{array}\\\bar{p}^{3}if\,m=3\end{cases} $$\end{document}

That implies that, if we draw a random individual from the population, and then consider its own p-score, and the product of its own p-score and the p-score of the other two members, this results inCov(p,pq1q2)=E[p2q1q2]−E[p]E[pq1q2]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq_{1}q_{2}\right)=E\left [p^{2}q_{1}q_{2}\right ]- E\left [p\right ]E\left [pq_{1}q_{2}\right ]$$\end{document}

With binary variables, that is equal toCov(p,pq1q2)=E[pq1q2]−E[p]E[pq1q2]=E[pq1q2](1−E[p])=p3(1−p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq_{1}q_{2}\right)=E\left [pq_{1}q_{2}\right ]- E\left [p\right ]E\left [pq_{1}q_{2}\right ]=E\left [pq_{1}q_{2}\right ]\left (1- E\left [p\right ]\right)=p^{3}\left (1- p\right)$$\end{document}

With Var(p)=p(1−p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)=p\left (1- p\right)$\end{document}, that implies thatCov(p,pq1q2)Var(p)=p2\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq_{1}q_{2}\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}=p^{2}$$\end{document}

The rule for selection with random group formation then becomes that Δp¯>0\begin{document}$\Delta \bar{p}\gt 0$\end{document} if and only if p2β^(1,1,1)>−β^(0,0,1)\begin{document}$p^{2}\hat{\beta }_{\left (1,1,1\right)}\gt - \hat{\beta }_{\left (0,0,1\right)}$\end{document}. This describes the dynamics in the following way. Assuming that β^(1,1,1)>0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{\left (1,1,1\right)}\gt 0$\end{document} and β^(0,0,1)<0\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{\left (0,0,1\right)}\lt 0$\end{document}, that means p=0\begin{document}$p=0$\end{document} and p=1\begin{document}$p=1$\end{document} are both attractors, separated by p=−β^(0,0,1)β^(1,1,1)\begin{document}$p=\sqrt{\frac{- \hat{\beta }_{\left (0,0,1\right)}}{\hat {\beta }_{\left (1,1,1\right)}}}$\end{document}.

sec.title: Relation to Smith et al., 2010
sec.p: In this section, I will discuss the relation between what I did in this paper and what (Smith et al., 2010) do. Smith et al., 2010 is an empirical study that tries to capture non-linearity. A first point of order is: linear or non-linear in what? For that, I would like to go back to Model 2 from Section 1 of this appendix.wi=α+β1,0pi+β0,1qi+εi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle w_{i}=\alpha +\beta _{1,0}p_{i}+\beta _{0,1}q_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}$$\end{document}

Here we assume that α=1\begin{document}$\alpha =1$\end{document}, β1,0=−1\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}=- 1$\end{document}, and β0,1=2\begin{document}$\beta _{0,1}=2$\end{document}. We assume that p-scores can only be 0 or 1, or, in other words, we assume that there are only cooperators and defectors in the population (or, in terms of Smith et al., 2010: cooperators and cheaters).

For a well-mixed population, we can now plot the fitnesses of cooperators (red) and defectors (blue) as a function of the frequency of cooperators (Appendix 2—figure 2, left panel). We can do the same for a population with relatedness 14\begin{document}$\frac{1}{4}$\end{document} (Appendix 2—figure 2, right panel). For relatedness r=0\begin{document}$r=0$\end{document} and r=14\begin{document}$r=\frac{1}{4}$\end{document}, cooperation is selected against at every frequency.

Increasing relatedness further, we would find that for r=12\begin{document}$r=\frac{1}{2}$\end{document} the lines coincide, and cooperation is neither selected for nor against. For r>12\begin{document}$r\gt \frac{1}{2}$\end{document} cooperation will be selected for at every frequency. This pattern is consistent with the fact that, as we have seen, the classical Hamilton’s rule works perfectly fine for Model 2; with c=−β1,0=1\begin{document}$c=- \beta _{1,0}=1$\end{document} and b=β0,1=2\begin{document}$b=\beta _{0,1}=2$\end{document}, cooperation is selected for if and only if rb>c\begin{document}$rb\gt c$\end{document}. The important thing to notice here is that the fitness of cooperators and the fitness of defectors, both as a function of the frequency of cooperators, are always parallel lines, regardless of relatedness.

caption.title: Fitnesses for Model 2.
caption.p: On the left, r=0\begin{document}$r=0$\end{document}, and the likelihood of being matched with a cooperator is the same for cooperators and defectors, and equal to the frequency of cooperators. On the right, r=14\begin{document}$r=\frac{1}{4}$\end{document} , where the probability of being matched with a cooperator is 14+34fC\begin{document}$\frac{1}{4}+\frac{3}{4}f_{C}$\end{document} for cooperators, and 34fC\begin{document}$\frac{3}{4}f_{C}$\end{document} for defectors, where fC\begin{document}$f_{C}$\end{document} is the frequency of cooperators.

sec.p: Model 3 from Section 1 extends Model 2 by adding an interaction term:wi=α+β1,0pi+β0,1qi+β1,1piqi+εi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle w_{i}=\alpha +\beta _{1,0}p_{i}+\beta _{0,1}q_{i}+\beta _{1,1}p_{i}q_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}$$\end{document}

Now we choose β1,0=−1\begin{document}$\beta _{1,0}=- 1$\end{document}, β0,1=1\begin{document}$\beta _{0,1}=1$\end{document}, and β1,1=1.\begin{document}$\beta _{1,1}=1.$\end{document} We again draw the fitnesses of cooperators and defectors, both at relatedness r=0\begin{document}$r=0$\end{document} (Appendix 2—figure 3, left panel) and at relatedness r=14\begin{document}$r=\frac{1}{4}$\end{document} (Appendix 2—figure 3, right panel). We have seen that the appropriate version of Hamilton’s rule here is Queller’s rule; r0,1b0,1+r1,1b1,1>c\begin{document}$r_{0,1}b_{0,1}+r_{1,1}b_{1,1}\gt c$\end{document} with c=−β1,0=1\begin{document}$c=- \beta _{1,0}=1$\end{document}, b0,1=β0,1=1\begin{document}$b_{0,1}=\beta _{0,1}=1$\end{document}, and b1,1=β1,1=1\begin{document}$b_{1,1}=\beta _{1,1}=1$\end{document}. The fitnesses of cooperators and defectors as functions of the frequency of cooperators are still straight lines, but they are no longer parallel.

The first thing to observe, therefore, is that a model with synergy, in which the classic version of Hamilton’s rule would be misspecified, and Queller’s rule would be well-specified, does not require the fitnesses as functions of the frequencies of cooperators to be non-linear. All that changes with the addition of the interaction term is that they stop being parallel.

caption.title: Fitnesses for Model 3.
caption.p: On the left,,r=0\begin{document}$r=0$\end{document} and on the right, r=14\begin{document}$r=\frac{1}{4}$\end{document}. The lines are still straight, but no longer parallel.

sec.p: Smith et al., 2010 is an effort to capture non-linearities in the way fitnesses depend on the frequency of cooperators. That, therefore, goes beyond the step from Model 2 to Model 3. Whether it uses the right method to capture those non-linearities, we will come back to in a second, but it is important to realize that also without these non-linearities, the classic version of Hamilton’s rule can be too limiting to accurately describe selection. Here, I should add that this implies that we were wrong in Wu et al., 2013, when we suggested that

“for this experiment, it seems unnecessary to use the generalized Hamilton’s rule, if instead the Malthusian fitness is adopted. In other words, the Wrightian fitness approach calls for a generalization of Hamilton’s rule, whereas the Malthusian fitness approach does not (or at least not in a drastic way, as Malthusian fitnesses are almost linear in the frequency of cooperators).”

Using Malthusian fitnesses, the functions were close to linear, but not close to parallel, and therefore also here, Hamilton’s rule needs generalizing - albeit in a different way than Smith et al., 2010 did.

The cooperation that is observed in the Myxococcus xanthus studied in Smith et al., 2010 is not a good match with a model where individuals are matched in pairs for an interaction that determines their fitnesses. These microbes cooperate in large groups, and a better match would therefore be the n-player public goods games studied in van Veelen, 2018a. There, we see that simple, straightforward ways to describe synergies (or anti-synergies) can easily lead to fitnesses not being linear in the frequency of cooperators.

The way Smith et al., 2010 try to capture those, however, is not free of complications. We addressed those in Wu et al., 2013, and I summarized them, shortly, in van Veelen, 2018a. One of the issues is that most of the non-linearity Smith et al., 2010 pick up is the result of considering Wrightian fitness rather than Malthusian fitness. In a continuous time model with a constant growth rate, the population size at time t\begin{document}$t$\end{document} is Nt=emtN0\begin{document}$N\left (t\right)=e^{mt}N\left (0\right)$\end{document}, where m\begin{document}$m$\end{document} is the Malthusian fitness. In a discrete time model with a constant average number of offspring per individual, the population at time t\begin{document}$t$\end{document} is Nt=wtN0\begin{document}$N\left (t\right)=w^{t}N\left (0\right)$\end{document}, where w\begin{document}$w$\end{document} is the Wrightian fitness. If we take m=lnw\begin{document}$m=lnw$\end{document}, these are the same, and if w\begin{document}$w$\end{document} is close to 1, then m\begin{document}$m$\end{document} can be approximated by w−1\begin{document}$w- 1$\end{document}. That also implies that if w\begin{document}$w$\end{document} is close to 1 (or, equivalently, if m\begin{document}$m$\end{document} is close to 0), one is locally linear if the other is too. However, in the experiment in Smith et al., 2010 the aggregate fitness effects are not small, and what is highly nonlinear in terms of Wrightian fitness is close to linear in Malthusian fitness.

Another complication is that the Taylor coefficients that Smith et al., 2010 find are the result of a combination of the data and the choice of a functional form they choose to first apply to their data. That means that a different choice of a functional form would have given different Taylor coefficients, while the in-between transformation can also be skipped. Also, the number of Taylor coefficients is larger than the dimensionality of the data, which are based on averages for 6 frequencies. For more details on these complications, I would like to refer to Wu et al., 2013 and van Veelen, 2018a. A nice detail is that if we consider the way the fitnesses of cooperators and defectors compare when using Malthusian fitnesses, then a comparison of the slopes suggests anti-synergies, which leads to a stable mix of cooperators and cheaters, already in the absence of population structure, much like what is suggested by Archetti and Scheuring, 2011; Archetti and Scheuring, 2012; Archetti, 2018

Besides these technical complications, Smith et al., 2010 is also different, in the sense that it is an empirical paper. It does not contain the Generalized Price equation, it contains no insights regarding how to derive population genetic dynamics from the Generalized Price equation, or how to derive the appropriate rules from those, and it has a very different approach to separating fitness effects and population structure.

sec.title: 2.1 Price-like equation 1, applied to Model 1
sec.p: As a finger exercise, we first apply Price-like equation 1 to Model 1. That helps make a few observations that are relevant when we minimize squared errors, not in a statistical setting, but in a setting with a model.

We get the Price-like equation 1 from minimizing the sum of squared errors, relative to Model 1. The true parameters are indicated by β0\begin{document}$\beta _{0}$\end{document} and β1\begin{document}$\beta _{1}$\end{document}, their estimates by β^0\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{0}$\end{document} and β^1\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{1}$\end{document}. The actual errors are indicated by εi\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{i}$\end{document}, and the errors, the squared sum of which we minimize, are indicated by ε^i\begin{document}$\hat{\varepsilon }_{i}$\end{document}.

The sum of squared errors is∑i=1nε^i2=∑i=1n(wi−(β^0+β^1pi))2=∑i=1n(β0+β1pi+εi−(β^0+β^1pi))2\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum _{i=1}^{n}\hat {\varepsilon }_{i}^{2}=\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (w_{i}- \left (\hat{\beta }_{0}+\hat {\beta }_{1}p_{i}\right)\right)^{2}=\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\beta _{0}+\beta _{1}p_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}- \left (\hat{\beta }_{0}+\hat{\beta }_{1}p_{i}\right)\right)^{2}$$\end{document}

If we minimize this, we begin with setting the derivative to β^0\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{0}$\end{document} to 0.−2∑i=1n(β0+β1pi+εi−(β^0+β^1pi))=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle - 2\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\beta _{0}+\beta _{1}p_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}- \left (\hat{\beta }_{0}+\hat{\beta }_{1}p_{i}\right)\right)=0$$\end{document}∑i=1n(β0−β^0)+∑i=1n(β1−β^1)pi+∑i=1nεi=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\beta _{0}- \hat {\beta }_{0}\right)+\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\beta _{1}- \hat {\beta }_{1}\right)p_{i}+\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}=0$$\end{document}β0−β^0+(β1−β^1)p¯+1n∑i=1nεi=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \beta _{0}- \hat {\beta }_{0}+\left (\beta _{1}- \hat{\beta }_{1}\right)\bar{p}+\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}=0$$\end{document}

Then we set the derivative to β^1\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{1}$\end{document} to 0−2∑i=1npi(β0+β1pi+εi−(β^0+β^1pi))=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle - 2\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}\left (\beta _{0}+\beta _{1}p_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}- \left (\hat {\beta }_{0}+\hat{\beta }_{1}p_{i}\right)\right)=0$$\end{document}∑i=1n(β0−β^0)pi+∑i=1n(β1−β^1)pi2+∑i=1nεipi=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\beta _{0}- \hat {\beta }_{0}\right)p_{i}+\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\beta _{1}- \hat{\beta }_{1}\right)p_{i}^{2}+\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}p_{i}=0$$\end{document}(β0−β^0)p¯+(β1−β^1)1n∑i=1npi2+1n∑i=1nεipi=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\beta _{0}- \hat{\beta }_{0}\right)\bar{p}+\left (\beta _{1}- \hat {\beta }_{1}\right)\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}+\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}p_{i}=0$$\end{document}

Although outside the Price equation literature, it is unusual to apply minimization of squared errors in a modeling context – where we know what the true model is, and therefore what β0\begin{document}$\beta _{0}$\end{document} and β1\begin{document}$\beta _{1}$\end{document} are – we can nonetheless still do it. In an infinite population, we can use that the errors have mean 0, which implies that limn→∞⁡1n∑i=1nεi=0\begin{document}$\underset{n\rightarrow \infty }{\mathit{lim}} \frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}=0$\end{document}, and we can use that the errors are uncorrelated with the p-scores, which implies that limn→∞⁡1n∑i=1nεipi=0\begin{document}$\underset{n\rightarrow \infty }{\mathit{lim}} \frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}p_{i}=0$\end{document}. Then we have two equations:β0−β^0+(β1−β^1)p¯=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \beta _{0}- \hat{\beta }_{0}+\left (\beta _{1}- \hat{\beta }_{1}\right)\bar{p}=0$$\end{document}(β0−β^0)p¯+(β1−β^1)1n∑i=1npi2=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\beta _{0}- \hat {\beta }_{0}\right)\bar{p}+\left (\beta _{1}- \hat{\beta }_{1}\right)\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}=0$$\end{document}

It is clear that both of these hold if β^0=β0\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{0}=\beta _{0}$\end{document} and β^1=β1\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{1}=\beta _{1}$\end{document}. In a statistical context, one cannot do this, because there we do not know the β0\begin{document}$\beta _{0}$\end{document} and β1\begin{document}$\beta _{1}$\end{document}, and the purpose of the estimation procedure is to get an estimate of those. Here, however, we do know what the actual model is, and we can simply pick β^0=β0\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{0}=\beta _{0}$\end{document} and β^1=β1\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{1}=\beta _{1}$\end{document}.

Of course, on its own, this is a futile exercise, as it unveils something that is not veiled. It does, however, illustrate that Price equation 1 applied to Model 1 gets the model right. This is an instructive benchmark for when we go on to allow for Price-like equations that are applied to non-matching models. An observation that may also help comparisons with this benchmark is that the errors that are found by the minimization coincide with the actual errors. Here we use that we chose β^0=β0\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{0}=\beta _{0}$\end{document} and β^1=β1\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{1}=\beta _{1}$\end{document}.ε^i=wi−(β^0+β^1pi)=β0+β1pi+εi−(β^0+β^1pi)=εi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \hat{\varepsilon }_{i}=w_{i}- \left (\hat{\beta }_{0}+\hat{\beta }_{1}p_{i}\right)=\beta _{0}+\beta _{1}p_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}- \left (\hat {\beta }_{0}+\hat{\beta }_{1}p_{i}\right)=\varepsilon _{i}$$\end{document}
for i…n\begin{document}$i\dots n$\end{document}.

If we would leave out the actual errors εi\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{i}$\end{document} at the very beginning, then the calculations come out the same. This would amount to assuming that εi=0\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{i}=0$\end{document} for all i\begin{document}$i$\end{document}, which is more than just assuming that errors have mean 0 (which implies that limn→∞⁡1n∑i=1nεi=0\begin{document}$\underset{n\rightarrow \infty }{\mathit{lim}} \frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}=0$\end{document}) and that they are uncorrelated with p-scores (which implies that limn→∞⁡1n∑i=1nεipi=0\begin{document}$\underset{n\rightarrow \infty }{\mathit{lim}} \frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}p_{i}=0$\end{document}). It can be seen, though, as a shortcut for assuming infinitely large populations, as we do here. In that case, we would get εi^=0\begin{document}$\hat{\varepsilon _{i}}=0$\end{document} for i=1,…,n\begin{document}$i=1,\dots,n$\end{document}.

I will not repeat this for Price equation 2 applied to Model 2, or Price equation 3 applied to Model 3, as I hope it is clear that all minimizations will result in the estimators coinciding with the actual coefficients. This is also verified in the shortcuts provided below in Detailed Calculations 2.4.

sec.title: 2.2 Price equation 1, applied to Model 2
sec.p: We now apply Price-like equation 1 to Model 2. The sum of squared errors is∑i=1nε^i2=∑i=1n(wi−(β^0+β^1pi))2=∑i=1n(γ0,0+γ1,0pi+γ0,1qi+εi−(β^0+β^1pi))2\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum _{i=1}^{n}\hat{\varepsilon }_{i}^{2}=\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (w_{i}- \left (\hat{\beta }_{0}+\hat{\beta }_{1}p_{i}\right)\right)^{2}=\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\gamma _{0,0}+\gamma _{1,0}p_{i}+\gamma _{0,1}q_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}- \left (\hat{\beta }_{0}+\hat{\beta }_{1}p_{i}\right)\right)^{2}$$\end{document}

If we minimize this, we begin with setting the derivative to β^0\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{0}$\end{document} to 0.−2∑i=1n(γ0,0+γ1,0pi+γ0,1qi+εi−(β^0+β^1pi))=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle - 2\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\gamma _{0,0}+\gamma _{1,0}p_{i}+\gamma _{0,1}q_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}- \left (\hat{\beta }_{0}+\hat{\beta }_{1}p_{i}\right)\right)=0$$\end{document}n(γ0,0−β^0)+(γ1,0−β^1)∑i=1npi+γ0,1∑i=1nqi+∑i=1nεi=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle n\left (\gamma _{0,0}- \hat{\beta }_{0}\right)+\left (\gamma _{1,0}- \hat{\beta }_{1}\right)\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}+\gamma _{0,1}\sum _{i=1}^{n}q_{i}+\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}=0$$\end{document}(γ0,0−β^0)+(γ1,0+γ0,1−β^1)p¯+1n∑i=1nεi=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\gamma _{0,0}- \hat{\beta }_{0}\right)+\left (\gamma _{1,0}+\gamma _{0,1}- \hat{\beta }_{1}\right)\bar{p}+\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}=0$$\end{document}

In the last step, we use that p¯=q¯\begin{document}$\bar{p}=\bar{q}$\end{document}. Then we set the derivative to β^1\begin{document}$\hat {\beta }_{1}$\end{document} to 0−2∑i=1npi(γ0,0+γ1,0pi+γ0,1qi+εi−(β^0+β^1pi))=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle - 2\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}\left (\gamma _{0,0}+\gamma _{1,0}p_{i}+\gamma _{0,1}q_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}- \left (\hat {\beta }_{0}+\hat{\beta }_{1}p_{i}\right)\right)=0$$\end{document}(γ0,0−β^0)∑i=1npi+(γ1,0−β^1)∑i=1npi2+γ0,1∑i=1npiqi+∑i=1nεipi=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\gamma _{0,0}- \hat {\beta }_{0}\right)\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}+\left (\gamma _{1,0}- \hat{\beta }_{1}\right)\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}+\gamma _{0,1}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}q_{i}+\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}p_{i}=0$$\end{document}(γ0,0−β^0)p¯+(γ1,0−β^1)1n∑i=1npi2+γ0,11n∑i=1npiqi+1n∑i=1nεipi=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\gamma _{0,0}- \hat {\beta }_{0}\right)\bar{p}+\left (\gamma _{1,0}-\hat {\beta }_{1}\right)\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}+\gamma _{0,1}\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}q_{i}+\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}p_{i}=0$$\end{document}

In an infinite population, we can use that the errors are assumed to have mean 0, which implies that 1n∑i=1nεi\begin{document}$\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}$\end{document} becomes 0 for large n\begin{document}$n$\end{document}. We also use that the errors are uncorrelated with the p-scores, which implies that 1n∑i=1nεipi\begin{document}$\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}p_{i}$\end{document} also becomes 0 for large n\begin{document}$n$\end{document}. The we multiply the first equation by p¯\begin{document}$\bar{p}$\end{document}, which gives us two equations:(γ0,0−β^0)p¯+(γ1,0+γ0,1−β^1)p¯2=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\gamma _{0,0}- \hat{\beta }_{0}\right)\bar{p}+\left (\gamma _{1,0}+\gamma _{0,1}- \hat{\beta }_{1}\right)\bar{p}^{2}=0$$\end{document}

and(γ0,0−β^0)p¯+(γ1,0−β^1)1n∑i=1npi2+γ0,11n∑i=1npiqi=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\gamma _{0,0}- \hat{\beta }_{0}\right)\bar{p}+\left (\gamma _{1,0}- \hat{\beta }_{1}\right)\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}+\gamma _{0,1}\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}q_{i}=0$$\end{document}

These combine to(γ1,0+γ0,1−β^1)p¯2=(γ1,0−β^1)1n∑i=1npi2+γ0,11n∑i=1npiqi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\gamma _{1,0}+\gamma _{0,1}- \hat {\beta }_{1}\right)\bar{p}^{2}=\left (\gamma _{1,0}- \hat {\beta }_{1}\right)\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}+\gamma _{0,1}\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}q_{i}$$\end{document}0=(γ1,0−β^1)(1n∑i=1npi2−1n2(∑i=1npi)2)+γ0,1(1n∑i=1npiqi−1n2(∑i=1npi)2)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle 0=\left (\gamma _{1,0}- \hat {\beta }_{1}\right)\left (\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}- \frac{1}{n^{2}}\left (\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}\right)^{2}\right)+\gamma _{0,1}\left (\frac{1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}q_{i}- \frac{1}{n^{2}}\left (\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}\right)^{2}\right)$$\end{document}

With ∑i=1npi=∑i=1nqi\begin{document}$\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}=\sum _{i=1}^{n}q_{i}$\end{document}, this is also0=(γ1,0−β1)Var(p)+γ0,1Cov(p,q)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle 0=\left (\gamma _{1,0}- \beta _{1}\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)+\gamma _{0,1}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)$$\end{document}

orβ^1=γ1,0+γ0,1Cov(p,q)Var(p)=γ1,0+rγ0,1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \hat {\beta }_{1}=\gamma _{1,0}+\gamma _{0,1}\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}=\gamma _{1,0}+r\gamma _{0,1}$$\end{document}

Then combining with the first equation gives(γ0,0−β^0)+(γ1,0+γ0,1−(γ1,0+γ0,1r))p¯=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\gamma _{0,0}- \hat {\beta }_{0}\right)+\left (\gamma _{1,0}+\gamma _{0,1}- \left (\gamma _{1,0}+\gamma _{0,1}r\right)\right)\bar{p}=0$$\end{document}β^0=γ0,0+(1−r)p¯γ0,1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \hat {\beta }_{0}=\gamma _{0,0}+\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}\gamma _{0,1}$$\end{document}

If we now go back to the errors, we find thatε^i=wi−(β^0+β^1pi)=γ0,0+γ1,0pi+γ0,1qi+εi−(γ0,0+(1−r)p¯γ0,1+(γ1,0+rγ0,1)pi)=γ0,1(qi−((1−r)p¯+rpi))+εi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \hat {\varepsilon }_{i} &= w_{i}- \left (\hat{\beta }_{0}+\hat{\beta }_{1}p_{i}\right) \\&= \gamma _{0,0}+\gamma _{1,0}p_{i}+\gamma _{0,1}q_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}- \left (\gamma _{0,0}+\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}\gamma _{0,1}+\left (\gamma _{1,0}+r\gamma _{0,1}\right)p_{i}\right)\\&= \gamma _{0,1}\left (q_{i}- \left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+rp_{i}\right)\right)+\varepsilon _{i}$$\end{document}

for all i=1,…,n\begin{document}$i=1,\dots,n$\end{document}. The errors, the squared sum of which is minimized, therefore do not coincide with the actual errors and include γ0,1\begin{document}$\gamma _{0,1}$\end{document} times the gap between qi\begin{document}$q_{i}$\end{document} and 1−rp¯+rpi\begin{document}$\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+rp_{i}$\end{document}. The first is the q-score of individual i\begin{document}$i$\end{document}, the second would be a predictor for qi\begin{document}$q_{i}$\end{document} based on p¯\begin{document}$\bar{p}$\end{document} and pi\begin{document}$p_{i}$\end{document}. This part represents the misspecification-induced part of the estimated errors.

If we again assume εi=0\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{i}=0$\end{document} for all i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} as a shortcut for assuming an infinitely large population, then ε^i=γ0,1(qi−((1−r)p¯+rpi))\begin{document}$\hat{\varepsilon }_{i}=\gamma _{0,1}\left (q_{i}- \left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+rp_{i}\right)\right)$\end{document} only reflects the misspecification.

sec.title: 2.3 Price equation 2, applied to Model 3
sec.p: We now apply Price-like equation 2 to Model 3. The derivation is rather boring, but there is no way around it. The sum of squared errors is∑i=1nε^i2=∑i=1n(δ0,0+δ1,0pi+δ0,1qi+δ1,1piqi+εi−(γ^0,0+γ^1,0pi+γ^0,1qi))2\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum _{i=1}^{n}\hat{\varepsilon }_{i}^{2}=\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\delta _{0,0}+\delta _{1,0}p_{i}+\delta _{0,1}q_{i}+\delta _{1,1}p_{i}q_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}- \left (\hat{\gamma }_{0,0}+\hat {\gamma }_{1,0}p_{i}+\hat {\gamma }_{0,1}q_{i}\right)\right)^{2}$$\end{document}

If we minimize this, we begin with setting the derivative to γ^0,0\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{0,0}$\end{document} to 0.−2∑i=1n(δ0,0+δ1,0pi+δ0,1qi+δ1,1piqi+εi−(γ^0,0+γ^1,0pi+γ^0,1qi))=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle - 2\sum _{i=1}^{n}\left (\delta _{0,0}+\delta _{1,0}p_{i}+\delta _{0,1}q_{i}+\delta _{1,1}p_{i}q_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}- \left (\hat{\gamma }_{0,0}+\hat {\gamma }_{1,0}p_{i}+\hat{\gamma }_{0,1}q_{i}\right)\right)=0$$\end{document}n(δ0,0−γ^0,0)+(δ1,0−γ^1,0)∑i=1npi+(δ0,1−γ^0,1)∑i=1nqi+δ1,1∑i=1npiqi+∑i=1nεi=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle n\left (\delta _{0,0}-\hat{\gamma }_{0,0}\right)+\left (\delta _{1,0}- \hat{\gamma }_{1,0}\right)\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}+\left (\delta _{0,1}- \hat{\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\sum _{i=1}^{n}q_{i}+\delta _{1,1}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}q_{i}+\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}=0$$\end{document}

Then we set the derivative to γ^1,0\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{1,0}$\end{document} to 0−2∑i=1npi(δ0,0+δ1,0pi+δ0,1qi+δ1,1piqi+εi−(γ^0,0+γ^1,0pi+γ^0,1qi))=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle - 2\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}\left (\delta _{0,0}+\delta _{1,0}p_{i}+\delta _{0,1}q_{i}+\delta _{1,1}p_{i}q_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}- \left (\hat{\gamma }_{0,0}+\hat{\gamma }_{1,0}p_{i}+\hat {\gamma }_{0,1}q_{i}\right)\right)=0$$\end{document}(δ0,0−γ^0,0)∑i=1npi+(δ1,0−γ^1,0)∑i=1npi2+(δ0,1−γ^0,1)∑i=1npiqi+δ1,1∑i=1npi2qi+∑i=1nεipi=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{0,0}- \hat{\gamma }_{0,0}\right)\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}+\left (\delta _{1,0}- \hat{\gamma }_{1,0}\right)\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}+\left (\delta _{0,1}- \hat{\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}q_{i}+\delta _{1,1}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}q_{i}+\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}p_{i}=0$$\end{document}

Finally, we set the derivative to γ^0,1\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{0,1}$\end{document} to 0−2∑i=1nqi(δ0,0+δ1,0pi+δ0,1qi+δ1,1piqi+εi−(γ0,0+γ^1,0pi+γ^0,1qi))=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle - 2\sum _{i=1}^{n}q_{i}\left (\delta _{0,0}+\delta _{1,0}p_{i}+\delta _{0,1}q_{i}+\delta _{1,1}p_{i}q_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}- \left (\gamma _{0,0}+\hat{\gamma }_{1,0}p_{i}+\hat{\gamma }_{0,1}q_{i}\right)\right)=0$$\end{document}(δ0,0−γ^0,0)∑i=1nqi+(δ1,0−γ^1,0)∑i=1npiqi+(δ0,1−γ^0,1)∑i=1nqi2+δ1,1∑i=1npiqi2+∑i=1nεiqi=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{0,0}- \hat {\gamma }_{0,0}\right)\sum _{i=1}^{n}q_{i}+\left (\delta _{1,0}- \hat{\gamma }_{1,0}\right)\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}q_{i}+\left (\delta _{0,1}- \hat {\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\sum _{i=1}^{n}q_{i}^{2}+\delta _{1,1}\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}q_{i}^{2}+\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}q_{i}=0$$\end{document}

If we then use that limn→∞⁡1n∑i=1nεi=limn→∞⁡1n∑i=1nεipi=limn→∞⁡1n∑i=1nεiqi=0\begin{document}$\frac{\underset{n\rightarrow \infty }{\mathit{lim}} 1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}=\frac{\underset{n\rightarrow \infty }{\mathit{lim}} 1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}p_{i}=\frac{\underset{n\rightarrow \infty }{\mathit{lim}} 1}{n}\sum _{i=1}^{n}\varepsilon _{i}q_{i}=0$\end{document}, we can rewrite these three equations as(δ0,0−γ^0,0)+(δ1,0−γ^1,0)p¯+(δ0,1−γ^0,1)q¯+δ1,1pq¯=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{0,0}- \hat {\gamma }_{0,0}\right)+\left (\delta _{1,0}- \hat{\gamma }_{1,0}\right)\bar{p}+\left (\delta _{0,1}- \hat{\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\bar{q}+\delta _{1,1}\overline{pq}=0$$\end{document}(δ0,0−γ^0,0)p¯+(δ1,0−γ^1,0)p2¯+(δ0,1−γ^0,1)pq¯+δ1,1p2q¯=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{0,0}- \hat{\gamma }_{0,0}\right)\bar{p}+\left (\delta _{1,0}- \hat{\gamma }_{1,0}\right)\overline{p^2}+\left (\delta _{0,1}- \hat{\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\overline{pq}+\delta _{1,1}\overline{p^{2}q}=0$$\end{document}(δ0,0−γ^0,0)q¯+(δ1,0−γ^1,0)pq¯+(δ0,1−γ^0,1)q2¯+δ1,1pq2¯=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{0,0}- \hat {\gamma }_{0,0}\right)\bar{q}+\left (\delta _{1,0}- \hat{\gamma }_{1,0}\right)\overline{pq}+\left (\delta _{0,1}-\hat {\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\overline{q^{2}}+\delta _{1,1}\overline{pq^{2}}=0$$\end{document}

If we multiply the first equation by p¯\begin{document}$\bar{p}$\end{document}, it becomes(δ0,0−γ^0,0)p¯+(δ1,0−γ^1,0)(p¯)2+(δ0,1−γ^0,1)(p¯)(q¯)+δ1,1(p¯)(pq¯)=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{0,0}- \hat {\gamma }_{0,0}\right)\bar{p}+\left (\delta _{1,0}- \hat {\gamma }_{1,0}\right)\left (\bar{p}\right)^{2}+\left (\delta _{0,1}- \hat{\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\left (\bar{p}\right)\left (\bar{q}\right)+\delta _{1,1}\left (\bar{p}\right)\left (\overline{pq}\right)=0$$\end{document}

Combining it with the second equation, we get(δ1,0−γ^1,0)((p¯)2−p2¯)+(δ0,1−γ^0,1)((p¯)(q¯)−pq¯)+δ1,1((p¯)(pq¯)−p2q¯)=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{1,0}- \hat {\gamma }_{1,0}\right)\left (\left (\bar{p}\right)^{2}- \overline{p^{2}}\right)+\left (\delta _{0,1}- \hat{\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\left (\left (\bar{p}\right)\left (\bar{q}\right)- \overline{pq}\right)+\delta _{1,1}\left (\left (\bar{p}\right)\left (\overline{pq}\right)- \overline{p^{2}q}\right)=0$$\end{document}

If we multiply the first equation by q¯\begin{document}$\bar{q}$\end{document}, and combine it with the third equation, we get(δ1,0−γ^1,0)((p¯)(q¯)−pq¯)+(δ0,1−γ^0,1)((q¯)(q¯)−q2¯)+δ1,1((q¯)(pq¯)−pq2¯)=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{1,0}- \hat{\gamma }_{1,0}\right)\left (\left (\bar{p}\right)\left (\bar{q}\right)- \overline{pq}\right)+\left (\delta _{0,1}- \hat {\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\left (\left (\bar{q}\right)\left (\bar{q}\right)- \overline{q^{2}}\right)+\delta _{1,1}\left (\left (\bar{q}\right)\left (\overline{pq}\right)- \overline{pq^{2}}\right)=0$$\end{document}

This can be written more succinctly as(δ1,0−γ^1,0)Var(p)+(δ0,1−γ^0,1)Cov(p,q)+δ1,1Cov(p,pq)=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{1,0}- \hat {\gamma }_{1,0}\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)+\left (\delta _{0,1}- \hat{\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)+\delta _{1,1}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)=0$$\end{document}(δ1,0−γ^1,0)Cov(p,q)+(δ0,1−γ^0,1)Var(q)+δ1,1Cov(q,pq)=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{1,0}- \hat{\gamma }_{1,0}\right)\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)+\left (\delta _{0,1}- \hat{\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)+\delta _{1,1}\mathrm{Cov}\left (q,pq\right)=0$$\end{document}

If we multiply the second equation with Var(p)Cov(p,q)\begin{document}$\frac{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}$\end{document}, it becomes(δ1,0−γ^1,0)Var(p)+(δ0,1−γ^0,1)Var(q)Var(p)Cov(p,q)+δ1,1Cov(q,pq)Var(p)Cov(p,q)=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{1,0}- \hat {\gamma }_{1,0}\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)+\left (\delta _{0,1}- \hat {\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\frac{\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}+\delta _{1,1}\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (q,pq\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}=0$$\end{document}

Combining that with the first equation gives us(δ0,1−γ^0,1)Cov(p,q)+δ1,1Cov(p,pq)=(δ0,1−γ^0,1)Var(q)Var(p)Cov(p,q)+δ1,1Cov(q,pq)Var(p)Cov(p,q)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{0,1}- \hat{\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)+\delta _{1,1}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)=\left (\delta _{0,1}- \hat {\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\frac{\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}+\delta _{1,1}\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (q,pq\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}$$\end{document}

which we rewrite as(δ0,1−γ^0,1)(Cov(p,q)−Var(q)Var(p)Cov(p,q))+δ1,1(Cov(p,pq)−Cov(q,pq)Var(p)Cov(p,q))=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{0,1}- \hat{\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\left (\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)- \frac{\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}\right)+\delta _{1,1}\left (\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)- \frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (q,pq\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}\right)=0$$\end{document}(δ0,1−γ^0,1)+δ1,1(Cov(p,pq)−Cov(q,pq)Var(p)Cov(p,q)Cov(p,q)−Var(q)Var(p)Cov(p,q))=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{0,1}- \hat{\gamma }_{0,1}\right)+\delta _{1,1}\left (\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)- \frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (q,pq\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}}{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)- \frac{\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}}\right)=0$$\end{document}δ0,1+δ1,1(Cov(p,pq)−Cov(q,pq)Var(p)Cov(p,q)Cov(p,q)−Var(q)Var(p)Cov(p,q))=γ^0,1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \delta _{0,1}+\delta _{1,1}\left (\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)- \frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (q,pq\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}}{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)- \frac{\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}}\right)=\hat {\gamma }_{0,1}$$\end{document}γ^0,1=δ0,1+δ1,1(Cov(p,q)Cov(p,pq)−Cov(q,pq)Var(p)(Cov(p,q))2−Var(p)Var(q))\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \hat {\gamma }_{0,1}=\delta _{0,1}+\delta _{1,1}\left (\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)- \mathrm{Cov}\left (q,pq\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}{\left (\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\right)^{2}- \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)}\right)$$\end{document}

This means we found γ^0,1\begin{document}$ \hat{\gamma }_{0,1}$\end{document}. In order to also find γ^1,0\begin{document}$\hat {\gamma }_{1,0}$\end{document}, we fill this in in the equation(δ1,0−γ^1,0)Var(p)+(δ0,1−γ^0,1)Cov(p,q)+δ1,1Cov(p,pq)=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{1,0}- \hat {\gamma }_{1,0}\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)+\left (\delta _{0,1}- \hat{\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)+\delta _{1,1}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)=0$$\end{document}

which gives us(δ1,0−γ^1,0)Var(p)−δ1,1(Cov(p,q)Cov(p,pq)−Cov(q,pq)Var(p)(Cov(p,q))2−Var(p)Var(q))Cov(p,q)+δ1,1Cov(p,pq)=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{1,0}- \hat{\gamma }_{1,0}\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right) &- \delta _{1,1}\left (\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)- \mathrm{Cov}\left (q,pq\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}{\left (\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\right)^{2}- \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)}\right)\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right) \\&+\delta _{1,1}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)=0 $$\end{document}

This we can rewrite as follows(δ1,0−γ^1,0)Var(p)−δ1,1((Cov(p,q))2Cov(p,pq)−Cov(p,q)Cov(q,pq)Var(p)(Cov(p,q))2−Var(p)Var(q))+δ1,1((Cov(p,q))2Cov(p,pq)−Cov(p,pq)Var(p)Var(q)(Cov(p,q))2−Var(p)Var(q))=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left(\delta _{1,0}- \hat{\gamma }_{1,0}\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right) &- \delta _{1,1}\left (\frac{\left (\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\right)^{2}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)- \mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\mathrm{Cov}\left (q,pq\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}{\left (\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\right)^{2}- \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)}\right)\\ &+\delta _{1,1}\left (\frac{\left (\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\right)^{2}\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)- \mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)}{\left (\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\right)^{2}- \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)}\right)=0 $$\end{document}(δ1,0−γ^1,0)Var(p)−δ1,1(Cov(p,pq)Var(p)Var(q)−Cov(p,q)Cov(q,pq)Var(p)(Cov(p,q))2−Var(p)Var(q))=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{1,0}- \hat{\gamma }_{1,0}\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)- \delta _{1,1}\left (\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)- \mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\mathrm{Cov}\left (q,pq\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}{\left (\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\right)^{2}-\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)}\right)=0$$\end{document}(δ1,0−γ^1,0)−δ1,1(Cov(p,pq)Var(q)−Cov(p,q)Cov(q,pq)(Cov(p,q))2−Var(p)Var(q))=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left (\delta _{1,0}- \hat {\gamma }_{1,0}\right)- \delta _{1,1}\left (\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)- \mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\mathrm{Cov}\left (q,pq\right)}{\left (\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\right)^{2}- \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)}\right)=0$$\end{document}

And thereby we foundγ^1,0=δ1,0−δ1,1(Cov(p,pq)Var(q)−Cov(p,q)Cov(q,pq)(Cov(p,q))2−Var(p)Var(q))\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \hat{\gamma }_{1,0}=\delta _{1,0}- \delta _{1,1}\left (\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)- \mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\mathrm{Cov}\left (q,pq\right)}{\left (\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\right)^{2}- \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)}\right)$$\end{document}

sec.title: 2.4. Shortcuts and simple checks
sec.p: Given that we know that for every choice for a model, the Generalized Price equation has w¯Δp¯\begin{document}$\bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}$\end{document} on the left-hand side, and something times Var(p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$\end{document} on the right-hand side, we can also, for an infinitely large population, fill in the model to find an expression for Δp¯\begin{document}$\Delta \bar{p}$\end{document}, multiply it by w¯\begin{document}$\bar{w}$\end{document} and divide by Var(p)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$\end{document} to recover what the core term in the Price-like equation would have to amount to. This is what we will do here, and it works for Price-like equations that are applied to the matching model. We begin with some additional details in describing states of the infinite population for the simple setting with asexual reproduction and a binary p-score.

sec.title: 2.4.1 Population states
sec.p: With asexual reproduction and a binary p-score, a population state in an infinite population model is characterized by the share of individuals that has a p-score of 1, which is p¯\begin{document}$\bar{p}$\end{document}. Every individual is matched with one partner, and since the q-score represents the p-score of the partner, the first observation is that these averages must be the same; p¯=q¯\begin{document}$\bar{p}=\bar{q}$\end{document}.

The second observation is that, with a binary p-score Ep2=Ep\begin{document}$E\left (p^{2}\right)=E\left (p\right)$\end{document}, and henceVar(p)=E(p2)−E2(p)=E(p)−E2(p)=p¯(1−p¯)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)=E\left (p^{2}\right)- E^{2}\left (p\right)=E\left (p\right)- E^{2}\left (p\right)=\bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)$$\end{document}

Similarly, Var(p)=Var(q)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)=\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)$\end{document} if every individual is matched with one partner. We will also refer to those with a p-score of 1 as cooperators and those with a p-score of 0 as defectors. This does not describe the trait very well in Model 1, but it is consistent across models.

The population structure is characterized by relatedness r\begin{document}$r$\end{document}, which determines the probabilities with which the two types are matched with themselves and each other.P(qi=1∣pi=1)=(1−r)p¯+r\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P\left (q_{i}=1\mid p_{i}=1\right)=\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r$$\end{document}P(qi=1∣pi=0)=(1−r)p¯\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P\left (q_{i}=1\mid p_{i}=0\right)=\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}$$\end{document}P(qi=0∣pi=0)=(1−r)(1−p¯)+r\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P\left (q_{i}=0\mid p_{i}=0\right)=\left (1- r\right)\left (1- \bar{p}\right)+r$$\end{document}P(qi=0∣pi=1)=(1−r)(1−p¯)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P\left (q_{i}=0\mid p_{i}=1\right)=\left (1- r\right)\left (1- \bar{p}\right)$$\end{document}

Another way to write this is r=P(qi=1∣pi=1)−P(qi=1∣pi=0)\begin{document}$r=P\left (q_{i}=1\mid p_{i}=1\right)- P\left (q_{i}=1\mid p_{i}=0\right)$\end{document}, which justifies thinking of r\begin{document}$r$\end{document} as the additional probability of being matched to a type, if it is the same type as one is oneself (see van Veelen et al., 2017).

In an infinite population, these probabilities determine the shares of different types of pairs in a straightforward way. If f0\begin{document}$f_{0}$\end{document} is the share of pairs in which both have a p-score of 0, f1\begin{document}$f_{1}$\end{document} is the share of pairs in which one has a p-score of 0, and the other a p-score of 1, and f2\begin{document}$f_{2}$\end{document} is the share of pairs in which both have a p-score of 1, then these shares are given byf0=(1−r)(1−p¯)2+r(1−p¯)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle f_{0}=\left (1- r\right)\left (1- \bar{p}\right)^{2}+r\left (1- \bar{p}\right)$$\end{document}f1=(1−r)2p¯(1−p¯)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle f_{1}=\left (1- r\right)2\bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)$$\end{document}f2=(1−r)p¯2+rp¯\begin{document}$$\displaystyle f_{2}=\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}^{2}+r\bar{p}$$\end{document}

This implies that, in this simple setting, with a binary p-score, and every individual being matched with one other individual, there is a straightforward expression for Cov(p,q)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)$\end{document}.Cov(p,q)=E(pq)−E(p)E(q)=f2−p¯q¯=f2−p¯2=(1−r)p¯2+rp¯−p¯2=rp¯−rp¯2=rp¯(1−p¯)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right) &=E\left (pq\right)- E\left (p\right)E\left (q\right)=f_{2}- \bar{p}\bar{q}=f_{2}- \bar{p}^{2}=\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}^{2}+r\bar{p}- \bar{p}^{2} \\ &=r\bar{p}- r\bar{p}^{2}=r\bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right) $$\end{document}

This is useful for calculating r\begin{document}$r$\end{document} in Model 2, which is also r0,1\begin{document}$r_{0,1}$\end{document} in Model 3:r=r0,1=Cov(p,q)Var(p)=rp¯(1−p¯)p¯(1−p¯)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle r=r_{0,1}=\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}=\frac{r\bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)}{\bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)}$$\end{document}

For calculating r1,1\begin{document}$r_{1,1}$\end{document} in Model 3, and for calculating sb\begin{document}$s_{b}$\end{document} and sc\begin{document}$s_{c}$\end{document}, which feature in the condition if we apply Price-like equation 2 to Model 3, we will also need the following covariances. Here we again use the fact that they are binary, which means that, for instance p2q\begin{document}$p^{2}q$\end{document} is 1 if p\begin{document}$p$\end{document} and q\begin{document}$q$\end{document} are both 1, and 0 in all other cases.Cov(p,pq)=E(p2q)−E(p)E(pq)=f2−p¯f2=(1−p¯)f2=(1−p¯)((1−r)p¯2+rp¯)=p¯(1−p¯)((1−r)p¯+r)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)&=E\left (p^{2}q\right)- E\left (p\right)E\left (pq\right)=f_{2}- \bar{p}f_{2}=\left (1- \bar{p}\right)f_{2}=\left (1- \bar{p}\right)\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}^{2}+r\bar{p}\right)\\&=\bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)$$\end{document}

with p¯=q¯\begin{document}$\bar{p}=\bar{q}$\end{document} , alsoCov(q,pq)=E(pq2)−E(q)E(pq)=f2−q¯f2=f2−p¯f2=Cov(p,pq)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathrm{Cov}\left (q,pq\right)=E\left (pq^{2}\right)- E\left (q\right)E\left (pq\right)=f_{2}- \bar{q}f_{2}=f_{2}- \bar{p}f_{2}=\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)$$\end{document}

These are useful for computing the r1,1\begin{document}$r_{1,1}$\end{document}, which features in Model 3.r1,1=Cov(p,pq)Var(p)=p¯(1−p¯)((1−r)p¯+r)p¯(1−p¯)=((1−r)p¯+r)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle r_{1,1}=\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)}{\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}=\frac{\bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)}{\bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)}=\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)$$\end{document}

There are two more bits of algebra that we will need below. This is not particularly exciting, but later we will be happy to have them available.sb=Cov(p,q)Cov(p,pq)−Cov(q,pq)Var(p)(Cov(p,q))2−Var(p)Var(q)=p¯(1−p¯)((1−r)p¯+r)(rp¯(1−p¯)−p¯(1−p¯))(rp¯(1−p¯))2−(p¯(1−p¯))2=((1−r)p¯+r)(r−1)(r2−1)=((1−r)p¯+r)(1−r)1−r2=(1−r)p¯+r1+r\begin{document}$$\displaystyle s_{b} &= \frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)- \mathrm{Cov}\left (q,pq\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)}{\left (\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\right)^{2}- \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)}\\ &= \frac{\bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\left (r\bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)- \bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)\right)}{\left (r\bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)\right)^{2}- \left (\bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)\right)^{2}}\\ &= \frac{\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\left (r- 1\right)}{\left (r^{2}- 1\right)}=\frac{\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\left (1- r\right)}{1- r^{2}}=\frac{\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r}{1+r}$$\end{document}

Because Cov(q,pq)=Cov(p,pq)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Cov}\left (q,pq\right)=\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)$\end{document}, we find thatsc=Cov(p,pq)Var(q)−Cov(p,q)Cov(q,pq)(Cov(p,q))2−Var(p)Var(q)=−sb\begin{document}$$\displaystyle s_{c}=\frac{\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,pq\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)- \mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\mathrm{Cov}\left (q,pq\right)}{\left (\mathrm{Cov}\left (p,q\right)\right)^{2}- \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)\mathrm{Var}\left (q\right)}=- s_{b}$$\end{document}

sec.title: 2.4.2 Model 1
sec.p: Model 1 iswi=β0+β1pi+εi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle w_{i}=\beta _{0}+\beta _{1}p_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}$$\end{document}

In an infinite population, this means that the average fitness of “cooperators” and “defectors” isw¯C=β0+β1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}_{C}=\beta _{0}+\beta _{1}$$\end{document}w¯D=β0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}_{D}=\beta _{0}$$\end{document}

The overall average fitness isw¯=p¯(β0+β1)+(1−p¯)β0=β0+p¯β1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}=\bar{p}\left (\beta _{0}+\beta _{1}\right)+\left (1- \bar{p}\right)\beta _{0}=\beta _{0}+\bar{p}\beta _{1}$$\end{document}

This makesΔp¯=p¯(β0+β1)w¯−p¯=p¯(β0+β1)β0+p¯β1−p¯(β0+p¯β1)β0+p¯β1=β1⋅p¯(1−p¯)w¯\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Delta \bar{p}=\frac{\bar{p}\left (\beta _{0}+\beta _{1}\right)}{\bar{w}}- \bar{p}=\frac{\bar{p}\left (\beta _{0}+\beta _{1}\right)}{\beta _{0}+\bar{p}\beta _{1}}- \frac{\bar{p}\left (\beta _{0}+\bar{p}\beta _{1}\right)}{\beta _{0}+\bar{p}\beta _{1}}=\frac{\beta _{1}\cdot \bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)}{\bar{w}}$$\end{document}

This implies thatw¯Δp¯=β1⋅p¯(1−p¯)=β1⋅Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\beta _{1}\cdot \bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)=\beta _{1}\cdot \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

The Generalized Price equation in regression form implies that if we take statistical Model 1, thenw¯Δp¯=β^1⋅Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1}\cdot \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

That implies that we do not have to do the actual minimizing of the sum of squared errors that we have done in Detailed Calculations 2.4.1 to conclude that β^1=β1\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{1}=\beta _{1}$\end{document} if we apply Price-like equation 1 to Model 1.

sec.title: 2.4.3 Model 2
sec.p: Model 2 iswi=γ0,0+γ1,0pi+γ0,1qi+εi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle w_{i}=\gamma _{0,0}+\gamma _{1,0}p_{i}+\gamma _{0,1}q_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}$$\end{document}

In an infinite population, this means that the average fitness of cooperators and defectors isw¯C=γ0,0+γ1,0+((1−r)p¯+r)γ0,1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}_{C}=\gamma _{0,0}+\gamma _{1,0}+\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\gamma _{0,1}$$\end{document}w¯D=γ0,0+(1−r)p¯γ0,1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}_{D}=\gamma _{0,0}+\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}\gamma _{0,1}$$\end{document}

The overall average fitness isw¯=p¯(γ0,0+γ1,0+((1−r)p¯+r)γ0,1)+(1−p¯)(γ0,0+(1−r)p¯γ0,1)=γ0,0+p¯(γ1,0+γ0,1)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}&=\bar{p}\left (\gamma _{0,0}+\gamma _{1,0}+\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\gamma _{0,1}\right)+\left (1- \bar{p}\right)\left (\gamma _{0,0}+\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}\gamma _{0,1}\right) \\ &=\gamma _{0,0}+\bar{p}\left (\gamma _{1,0}+\gamma _{0,1}\right) $$\end{document}

This makesΔp¯=p¯w¯Cw¯−p¯=p¯(γ0,0+γ1,0+((1−r)p¯+r)γ0,1)γ0,0+p¯(γ1,0+γ0,1)−p¯(γ0,0+p¯(γ1,0+γ0,1))γ0,0+p¯(γ1,0+γ0,1)=p¯(1−p¯)(γ1,0+rγ0,1)w¯\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Delta \bar{p}=\frac{\bar{p}\bar{w}_{C}}{\bar{w}}- \bar{p}&=\frac{\bar{p}\left (\gamma _{0,0}+\gamma _{1,0}+\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\gamma _{0,1}\right)}{\gamma _{0,0}+\bar{p}\left (\gamma _{1,0}+\gamma _{0,1}\right)}- \frac{\bar{p}\left (\gamma _{0,0}+\bar{p}\left (\gamma _{1,0}+\gamma _{0,1}\right)\right)}{\gamma _{0,0}+\bar{p}\left (\gamma _{1,0}+\gamma _{0,1}\right)}\\&=\frac{\bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)\left (\gamma _{1,0}+r\gamma _{0,1}\right)}{\bar{w}}$$\end{document}

This implies thatw¯Δp¯=(γ1,0+rγ0,1)⋅p¯(1−p¯)=(γ1,0+rγ0,1)⋅Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\left (\gamma _{1,0}+r\gamma _{0,1}\right)\cdot \bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)=\left (\gamma _{1,0}+r\gamma _{0,1}\right)\cdot \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

The Generalized Price equation in regression form implies that if we take statistical Model 2, thenw¯Δp¯=(γ^1,0+rγ^0,1)⋅Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\left (\hat {\gamma }_{1,0}+r\hat {\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\cdot \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

That implies that we do not have to do the actual minimizing of the sum of squared errors to conclude that γ^1,0=γ1,0\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{1,0}=\gamma _{1,0}$\end{document} and γ^0,1=γ0,1\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{0,1}=\gamma _{0,1}$\end{document} if we apply Price-like equation 2 to Model 2.
With b=γ0,1\begin{document}$b=\gamma _{0,1}$\end{document} and −c=γ1,0\begin{document}$- c=\gamma _{1,0}$\end{document}, here we of course recognize Hamilton’s original rule.

The Generalized Price equation also implies that if we take statistical Model 1, then stillw¯Δp¯=β^1⋅Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\hat {\beta }_{1}\cdot \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

That implies that also here, we do not have to do the actual minimizing of the sum of squared errors that we did in Detailed Calculations 2.4.2 above to conclude that, if we apply the Generalized Price equation using statistical Model 1 to Model 2, we get β^1=γ1,0+rγ0,1\begin{document}$\hat{\beta }_{1}=\gamma _{1,0}+r\gamma _{0,1}$\end{document}. For other mismatches, this shortcut does not work, and we will have to do the actual minimization.

sec.title: 2.4.4 Model 3
sec.p: Model 3 iswi=δ0,0+δ1,0pi+δ0,1qi+δ1,1piqi+εi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle w_{i}=\delta _{0,0}+\delta _{1,0}p_{i}+\delta _{0,1}q_{i}+\delta _{1,1}p_{i}q_{i}+\varepsilon _{i}$$\end{document}

In an infinite population, this means that the average fitness of cooperators and defectors isw¯C=δ0,0+δ1,0+((1−r)p¯+r)(δ0,1+δ1,1)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}_{C}=\delta _{0,0}+\delta _{1,0}+\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\left (\delta _{0,1}+\delta _{1,1}\right)$$\end{document}w¯D=δ0,0+(1−r)p¯δ0,1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}_{D}=\delta _{0,0}+\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}\delta _{0,1}$$\end{document}

The overall average fitness isw¯=δ0,0+p¯(δ0,1+δ1,0)+p¯((1−r)p¯+r)δ1,1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}=\delta _{0,0}+\bar{p}\left (\delta _{0,1}+\delta _{1,0}\right)+\bar{p}\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\delta _{1,1}$$\end{document}

This makesΔp¯=p¯w¯Cw¯−p¯=p¯(δ0,0+δ1,0+((1−r)p¯+r)(δ0,1+δ1,1))1+p¯(δ0,1+δ1,0)+p¯((1−r)p¯+r)δ1,1−p¯(δ0,0+p¯(δ0,1+δ1,0)+p¯((1−r)p¯+r)δ1,1)1+p¯(δ0,1+δ1,0)+p¯((1−r)p¯+r)δ1,1=δ1,0p¯(1−p¯)+rδ0,1p¯(1−p¯)+((1−r)p¯+r)δ1,1p¯(1−p¯)w¯\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Delta \bar{p} =& \, \frac{\bar{p}\bar{w}_{C}}{\bar{w}}- \bar{p} \\ =& \, \frac{\bar{p}\left (\delta _{0,0}+\delta _{1,0}+\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\left (\delta _{0,1}+\delta _{1,1}\right)\right)}{1+\bar{p}\left (\delta _{0,1}+\delta _{1,0}\right)+\bar{p}\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\delta _{1,1}}\\ & - \frac{\bar{p}\left (\delta _{0,0}+\bar{p}\left (\delta _{0,1}+\delta _{1,0}\right)+\bar{p}\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\delta _{1,1}\right)}{1+\bar{p}\left (\delta _{0,1}+\delta _{1,0}\right)+\bar{p}\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\delta _{1,1}}\\ =& \, \frac{\delta _{1,0}\bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)+r\delta _{0,1}\bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)+\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\delta _{1,1}\bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right)}{\bar{w}} $$\end{document}

This implies thatw¯Δp¯=(δ1,0+rδ0,1+((1−r)p¯+r)δ1,1)⋅p¯(1−p¯)=(δ1,0+rδ0,1+((1−r)p¯+r)δ1,1)⋅Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p} &=\left (\delta _{1,0}+r\delta _{0,1}+\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\delta _{1,1}\right)\cdot \bar{p}\left (1- \bar{p}\right) \\&=\left (\delta _{1,0}+r\delta _{0,1}+\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\delta _{1,1}\right)\cdot \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right) $$\end{document}

The Generalized Price equation in regression form implies that if we take statistical Model 3, thenw¯Δp¯=(δ^1,0+rδ^0,1+((1−r)p¯+r)δ^1,1)⋅Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\left (\hat{\delta }_{1,0}+r\hat{\delta }_{0,1}+\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\hat{\delta }_{1,1}\right)\cdot \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

That implies that we do not have to do the actual minimizing of the sum of squared errors to conclude that δ^1,0=δ1,0\begin{document}$\hat{\delta }_{1,0}=\delta _{1,0}$\end{document}, δ^0,1=δ0,1\begin{document}$\hat{\delta }_{0,1}=\delta _{0,1}$\end{document}, and δ^1,1=δ1,1\begin{document}$\hat{\delta }_{1,1}=\delta _{1,1}$\end{document} if we apply Price-like equation 3 to Model 3.

sec.title: 2.4.5 Price-like equation 2, applied to Model 3
sec.p: The Generalized Price equation in regression form for Model 2 isw¯Δp¯=(γ^1,0+rγ^0,1)⋅Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{w}\Delta \bar{p}=\left (\hat {\gamma }_{1,0}+r\hat{\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\cdot \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}

If we apply this to Model 3, then this does not allow for a straightforward computation of γ^1,0\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{1,0}$\end{document} and γ^0,1\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{0,1}$\end{document} without having to do the actual minimization of the sum of squared errors. The reason for that is that now we have one equation, that is, we have γ^1,0+γ^0,1=\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{1,0}+\hat {\gamma }_{0,1}=$\end{document}δ1,0+rδ0,1+1−rp¯+rδ1,1\begin{document}$\delta _{1,0}+r\delta _{0,1}+\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\delta _{1,1}$\end{document}, and two variables, γ^1,0\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{1,0}$\end{document} and γ^0,1\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{0,1}$\end{document}. What we can do, however, is just verify that the γ^1,0\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{1,0}$\end{document} and γ^0,1\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{0,1}$\end{document} that we found in B4.3, work. There, we found thatγ^0,0=δ0,0−(1−r)p¯sbδ1,1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \hat {\gamma }_{0,0}=\delta _{0,0}- \left (1- r\right)\bar{p}s_{b}\delta _{1,1}$$\end{document}γ^1,0=δ1,0−scδ1,1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \hat {\gamma }_{1,0}=\delta _{1,0}- s_{c}\delta _{1,1}$$\end{document}γ^0,1=δ0,1+sbδ1,1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \hat {\gamma }_{0,1}=\delta _{0,1}+s_{b}\delta _{1,1}$$\end{document}

withsb=(1−r)p¯+r1+r\begin{document}$$\displaystyle s_{b}=\frac{\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r}{1+r}$$\end{document}sc=−(1−r)p¯+r1+r\begin{document}$$\displaystyle s_{c}=\frac{- \left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r}{1+r}$$\end{document}

If we then fill those in, we getw¯Δp¯=(γ^1,0+rγ^0,1)⋅Var(p)=(δ1,0−scδ1,1+r(δ0,1+sbδ1,1))⋅Var(p)=(δ1,0+rδ0,1+(rsb−sc)δ1,1)⋅Var(p)=(δ1,0+rδ0,1+((1−r)p¯+r)δ1,1)⋅Var(p)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin {aligned}\bar{w}\Delta \bar{p} &=\left (\hat {\gamma }_{1,0}+r\hat{\gamma }_{0,1}\right)\cdot \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right) =\left (\delta _{1,0}- s_{c}\delta _{1,1}+r\left (\delta _{0,1}+s_{b}\delta _{1,1}\right)\right)\cdot \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)\\&=\left (\delta _{1,0}+r\delta _{0,1}+\left (rs_{b}- s_{c}\right)\delta _{1,1}\right)\cdot \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)\\&=\left (\delta _{1,0}+r\delta _{0,1}+\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\delta _{1,1}\right)\cdot \mathrm{Var}\left (p\right)$$\end{document}
This is indeed what we saw above.

sec.title: Relation to the claim in Grafen, 1985a
sec.p: If the true model were Model 2, one would interpret γ^1,0\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{1,0}$\end{document} as the effect of having the gene on oneself. The Generalized Price equation in regression form for Model 2 applied to Model 3 gives, as we saw aboveγ^1,0=δ1,0+(1−r)p¯+r1+rδ1,1,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \hat {\gamma }_{1,0}=\delta _{1,0}+\frac{\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r}{1+r}\delta _{1,1},$$\end{document}

This is the lower red line in Appendix 2—figure 4 below. It is not a constant and cannot be interpreted as the effect of having the gene on oneself. We can search for a possible interpretation, though, by calculating the average effects of having the gene. We will begin by taking the perspective of those with the gene and calculating the difference between their actual fitness and what their fitness would have been, had they not had the gene (this is also referred to as the counterfactual method in van Veelen et al., 2017; van Veelen, 2018a). This amounts to δ1,0\begin{document}$\delta _{1,0}$\end{document} plus δ1,1\begin{document}$\delta _{1,1}$\end{document} times the probability that carriers are matched with another individual that has the gene.δ1,0+1−rp¯+rδ1,1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \delta _{1,0}+\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\delta _{1,1}$$\end{document}
In Appendix 2—figure 4 below, this is the second dashed blue line from the bottom.

We can also take the perspective of those without the gene and calculate the difference between what their fitness would have been if they had the gene and their actual fitness. This is δ1,0\begin{document}$\delta _{1,0}$\end{document} plus δ1,1\begin{document}$\delta _{1,1}$\end{document} times the probability that non-carriers are matched with an individual that has the gene.δ1,0+(1−r)p¯δ1,1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \delta _{1,0}+\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}\delta _{1,1}$$\end{document}
In Appendix 2—figure 4 below, this is the dashed blue line at the bottom.

Finally, one could also average these average effects over carriers and non-carriers. That would givep¯(δ1,0+((1−r)p¯+r)δ1,1)+(1−p¯)(δ1,0+(1−r)p¯δ1,1)=δ1,0+(1−r)p¯δ1,1+rp¯δ1,1=δ1,0+p¯δ1,1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{p}\left (\delta _{1,0}+\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\delta _{1,1}\right) &+\left (1- \bar{p}\right)\left (\delta _{1,0}+\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}\delta _{1,1}\right)\\&=\delta _{1,0}+\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}\delta _{1,1}+r\bar{p}\delta _{1,1}=\delta _{1,0}+\bar{p}\delta _{1,1}$$\end{document}

caption.title: Applying the Generalized Price equation for Model 2 to Model 3.
caption.p: For this figure, we chose Model 3 with δ1,0=−2\begin{document}$\delta _{1,0}=- 2$\end{document}, δ1,1=0\begin{document}$\delta _{1,1}=0$\end{document}, and δ1,1=3\begin{document}$\delta _{1,1}=3$\end{document}. The red lines are γ^1,0\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{1,0}$\end{document} (the lower one), and γ^0,1\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{0,1}$\end{document} (the higher one), which, when applied to Model 2, would have been the effect on the individual itself and the effect on the partner. The average effect on the individual itself is the lower unbroken blue line, which is accompanied by the average effect for the defectors (the dashed line below it) and the average effect for cooperators (the dashed line immediately above it). The average effect on the partner is the higher unbroken blue line, which is accompanied by the average effect for the defectors (the dashed line immediately below it) and the average effect for cooperators (the dashed line above it).

sec.p: In Appendix 2—figure 4 above, this is the lower unbroken blue line. We see that neither of these three matches the that we get from applying the Generalized Price equation for Model 2 to Model 3.

We can do the same for γ^0,1\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{0,1}$\end{document}. If the true model were Model 2, one would interpret γ^0,1\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{0,1}$\end{document} as the effect of having the gene on one’s partner. The Generalized Price equation in regression form for Model 2 applied to Model 3 givesγ^0,1=δ0,1+(1−r)p¯+r1+rδ1,1,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \hat {\gamma }_{0,1}=\delta _{0,1}+\frac{\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r}{1+r}\delta _{1,1},$$\end{document}

This is the higher up red line in Appendix 2—figure 4 above. This is not a constant either and cannot be interpreted as the effect of having the gene on the interaction partner. We will begin by taking the perspective of those with the gene and calculating the difference between the actual fitness of their partner and what their partner’s fitness would have been, had they not had the gene. This amounts to δ0,1\begin{document}$\delta _{0,1}$\end{document} plus δ1,1\begin{document}$\delta _{1,1}$\end{document} times the probability that carriers are matched with another individual that has the gene.δ0,1+((1−r)p¯+r)δ1,1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \delta _{0,1}+\left (\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}+r\right)\delta _{1,1}$$\end{document}
In Appendix 2—figure 4 above, this is the dashed blue line at the top.

We can also take the perspective of those without the gene, and calculate the difference between what their partner’s fitness would have been, if they themselves would have had the gene, and their actual fitness. This is δ0,1\begin{document}$\delta _{0,1}$\end{document} plus δ1,1\begin{document}$\delta _{1,1}$\end{document} times the probability that non-carriers are matched with an individual that has the gene.δ0,1+(1−r)p¯δ1,1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \delta _{0,1}+\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}\delta _{1,1}$$\end{document}
In Appendix 2—figure 4 above, this is the second dashed blue line from the top.

Finally, one could also average these average effects over carriers and non-carriers. That would giveδ0,1+(1−r)p¯δ1,1+rp¯δ1,1=δ0,1+p¯δ1,1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \delta _{0,1}+\left (1- r\right)\bar{p}\delta _{1,1}+r\bar{p}\delta _{1,1}=\delta _{0,1}+\bar{p}\delta _{1,1}$$\end{document}

In Appendix 2—figure 4 above, this is the higher up unbroken blue line. We see that also here, neither of these three matches the γ^0,1\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{0,1}$\end{document} that we get from applying the Generalized Price equation in regression form for Model 2 to Model 3.

Appendix 2—figure 4 illustrates this and visualizes that trying to understand the working of Model 3 through applying the Generalized Price equation for Model 2 on it is misleading. The values for γ^1,0\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{1,0}$\end{document} and γ^0,1\begin{document}$\hat{\gamma }_{0,1}$\end{document} that this results in do not coincide with the average effect on the individual itself and the average effect on the partner.

aff.institution: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology

body.p: Kin selection and inclusive fitness have generated significant controversy. This paper reconsiders the general form of Hamilton's rule in which benefits and costs are defined as regression coefficients, with higher-order coefficients being added to accommodate non-linear interactions. The paper is a landmark contribution to the field with compelling, systematic analysis, giving clarity to long-standing debates.

This manuscript reconsiders the "general form" of Hamilton's rule, in which "benefit" and "cost" are defined as regression coefficients. It points out that there is no reason to insist on Hamilton's rule of the form -c+br>0, and that, in fact, arbitrarily many terms (i.e. higher-order regression coefficients) can be added to Hamilton's rule to reflect nonlinear interactions. Furthermore, it argues that insisting on a rule of the form -c+br>0 can result in conditions that are true but meaningless and that statistical considerations should be employed to determine which form of Hamilton's rule is meaningful for a given dataset or model.
Comments on latest version:
The authors have provided a robust, valuable and detailed response to the previous reviews.
Comments from Reviewer #1: I have nothing further to add.

Comments from Reviewer #2: I appreciate the clarifications the author has made to the manuscript regarding (i) "sample covariance" terminology, (ii) the generality of the "generalized Price equation", and (iii) the distinction between the covariance and regression forms of the Price equation.
